name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: The first item on the agenda is the debate on the question for oral answer to the Commission on building an ambitious industrial policy strategy for the EU as a strategic priority for growth, jobs and innovation in Europe by Patrizia Toia, Martina Werner, Dan Nica, Kathleen Van Brempt, Krišjānis Kariņš, Anne Sander, Jerzy Buzek, Massimiliano Salini, on behalf of the Group of the Progressive Alliance of Social Democrats in the European Parliament and the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) (O-000047/2017 - B8-0319 / 2017) (2017/2732(RSP)).

name: Patrizia TOIA
text: author. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, European industry is the main economic activity and makes Europe the leading exporter in the world. 80% of the investment in research and development is concentrated in industry and many discoveries and researches are born there that have application in many other fields. We know that the continental manufacturing sector suffered a sharp drop in productivity during the crisis years and the employment rate dropped. Entire regions of our Europe have been deindustrialized and have gone into crisis. Only recently has there been a recovery in the share of the industrial sector in relation to European GDP. But today industry is at the crossroads, between innovation and loss of competitiveness, and the European Union must do its part, it must relaunch its own specific industrial policy. This is the meaning and purpose of the question. We call for a more specific and bolder European industrial policy, with a coherent and holistic action plan that goes precisely in the direction it is taking but which needs further impetus to support the competitiveness of our businesses, with active support from the Commission and also of the Member States, on the basis of some priority axes. The first is innovation. The industrial revolution is investing, supporting and shaking the entire industrial sector. Industry 4.0 is an indispensable step, especially for SMEs, for small production companies that cannot make it on their own. So you have to work side by side with companies. Smart manufacturing is the strong theme of this policy. Research clearly shows that companies with high and advanced digital manufacturing also have a higher productivity and revenue premium. So there is a very close link between smart manufacturing and the production capacity of companies. The EU must also foster convergence between different national systems. We cannot have a Europe with 27 industries 4.0. We need a convergence framework, a community framework, because today there is too great a diversity of performance in this field. There is a country that is front runner and the others that struggle, but this divergence is not good for the whole European economy. The European economy needs greater convergence, therefore to ensure that a more advanced smart manufacturing capacity is born in all states. But digital innovation is not just technological innovation, it is a change in business models, it is a change in the world of work. Therefore industrial policy must also go hand in hand with a training policy, preparing the necessary digital skills. The second point is investments. We have many tools that have been put in place. But I think there is a need, first of all, to strengthen those who have given more success, more results, and then to make them more complementary. I am thinking of the structural funds, I am thinking of Horizon. The industrial pillar of Horizon - I say this to the Commissioner because she is certainly sensitive to this - must also be managed more by industry, stronger also in terms of dedicated resources, because it has shown that it works well. And then I also think about the Juncker Plan. If the new Juncker Plan is to make significant investments for the transformation of European industry and the European economy, it must give much more to small and medium-sized enterprises and their capacity for innovation. Finally, internationalization. Here it is not enough to support export stimuli, it is necessary to support the strengthening of companies to position themselves within the global value chain, which is now European and international. We need a more balanced trade policy in the sense also of opening up, of having an open economy, but attentive to reciprocity and mutual benefits, also knowing how to defend - we tell the Commissioner which deals with international trade - with more defensive capacity than our industry, especially where there are countries that have a very strong production overcapacity.I don't have time to deal with the issue of the green economy and the digital economy.Let me just close by saying that there is time and need for a new European Research Council.

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: author. - Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the manufacturing industry represents today only 13% of the GDP in Europe, that is to say twice less than in 1980. This means that we are living in a deep crisis of competitiveness. Many jobs have been threatened, they are still under threat because we failed to anticipate the industrial revolution. For a long time, we forgot about our industry. As a result, we must now lean on his bedside, because our companies have been hit hard by international competition and the loss of their competitiveness. The renewal of European industry is a priority, as our industry makes a significant contribution to research and development. Without industry, there is no innovation and there is no growth. Certain regions of Europe, formerly industrial, saw the birth of their first technological hub and are becoming regions where start-ups rub shoulders with universities. This new lease of life is the hope for redevelopment of employment and new attractiveness for investors. But we need a truly integrated industrial policy. We need to bring out European champions who export abroad. European competition policy must not hinder the creation of these champions. We cannot treat industrial policy with a narrow view. It is therefore essential to give meaning to each of the tools that we use. I won't go into them in detail, my colleague, Ms. Toia, spoke about them. Finally, our industry needs visibility and stability, fiscal and legal, in order to be able to carry out long-term investments. To do this, we must also train our young generations in the professions of tomorrow, in particular in the digital sector. This will be the sine qua non for the future of European industry.

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I am very happy to have this opportunity for some further discussion of European industrial policy and grateful that European industry is thus being put in the spotlight as – I am quite sure – a major driver of growth, employment and innovation in Europe. The recent Commission reflection paper on harnessing globalisation likewise underlined the need for a strong industrial base in Europe. Some facts, very briefly: European industry provides 50 million direct jobs, equivalent to 20% of our European workforce. Europe is the global leader in many industrial sectors which supply high-value jobs, such as engineering, chemicals, pharmaceuticals, aeronautics and automotives, and European companies play a leading role in markets for future technologies. The Commission, as you know, has taken a novel approach from the outset  to supporting industrial competitiveness and transformation of the EU economy. In every single initiative that we take, we consider the impact on our industry and on jobs.  What have we done so far? For a start, we have been investing in innovation, and, of course, I mean here the opportunities being created by the investment plan and the Horizon 2020 programme. What, I think, is even more important is that direct investment for innovation is improving the climate for private investors. Then there was, for instance, our work last month on the European venture capital funds, added to which are the revamped tax and regulatory environment, the initiatives – over 200 – for further reduction and simplification under the regulatory fitness programme, and, of course, all of the measures under the single market strategy that we are working on.  We are also focusing on skills. Last year we took a radically new approach in our new Skills Agenda for Europe. In this way, for the first time really, as industry is very well placed in our new Skills Agenda, skills have come to the centre of the industrial policy agenda. In addition, we are focusing our policies on new technologies and new approaches. Let me just mention the Circular Economy Package, in which we are now providing very practical ways for industry to turn recycling of resources into strong real business opportunities.  Similarly, we are very clear about the fact that the future is digital. We are deploying all means across the policy agenda. We work from financing research to facilitating standard setting. For example, we want to ensure that our industries make a successful transition to this new digital age and we will soon be reviewing our policy on key enabling technologies. I think that this point should also be stressed because the policy dates from 2008 and a lot has changed since then – 3D printing and autonomous cars were unknown at that stage, so it is high time for a review.  Finally, we are providing sector-specific solutions when needed, from cars to steel, from space to defence. So I personally think, and I know that you know this, that we are now ready and very well prepared, as Ms Toia said, for a coherent ‘holistic European industrial strategy’.  This Commission is 100% committed to fostering a strong industrial base in Europe to face both the challenges of globalisation and, of course, the fourth industrial revolution. Our approach is result oriented. We need to take concrete actions to modernise the economy at the EU’s different levels – EU, national and regional. And we will coordinate national industrial strategies, in particular those related to digitalisation. One way of doing so is to continue the dialogue with industry and with the Member States, so on the last day of February I inaugurated the first European Industry Day, an event at which we all agreed to explore the priority areas, in other words people, territory and technologies.  Let me just refer briefly to each of them. As regards people, given the major transformation in the EU economy, we really need massive upskilling and reskilling of our workforce to avoid widening social gaps. Regarding territory, industrial transformation really happens at regional and local level, so we need to empower regions and to respond to the challenges that we are facing and, of course, make the best of the opportunities. And as far as technologies are concerned, more needs to be done to accelerate the spread of technology in order to close the productivity gap. That is the major issue here. The recent Commission reflection paper on harnessing globalisation picked out exactly the same three areas and points for Europe’s response to globalisation.  In its most recent discussion, last month, the Competitiveness Council   adopted conclusions on industry and for the first time in many years showed that there is wide agreement among Member States on the importance of industry and the need for a European industrial strategy. Not a single country was against this, so that was really a very strong signal from the Member States as well. As they say, we are all friends of industry now. The European Commission is the force for strengthening industrial competitiveness. Our efforts have to be bolstered by the Member States. And we also need Parliament’s support to put in place a legislative framework to facilitate industrial modernisation. We need to have an open debate on how Europe, working together, could do more for European industry. Finally, I also want to underline that when measuring our results, the results of our policies and activities, we could look far beyond the 20% target for manufacturing in our economy.  So once again, I would like to thank Parliament for today’s discussion. I am quite convinced that we need a common vision for the future of European industry, and your contribution and support are vital to that end.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, in a minute and a half I do not want to recall once again the numerical value of European industry. We will all talk during this discussion of important numbers, of small and medium-sized enterprises, of large companies and so on. I will emphasize only one thing: the support we decided to give a few years ago, reiterating it, clearly, starting with the Commission, starting with what was said by his predecessor, who is today the President of the European Parliament, Antonio Tajani. We have set ourselves the goal of reaching 20% ​​of the gross domestic product deriving from industry, but this has remained theoretical. Today we are in 2017 and we are at 15%. So let's be honest. If we give ourselves binding targets, which are very right, for example in the context of environmental protection policies in relation to the great emergency of climate change, but we do not give ourselves binding targets on the industrial sector, we do damage both to climate policies and to industry, because it means that, if those are binding and these are not as objectives, it means that those are not intended to protect the environment, but to modify and weaken the industry. So, since we as Europeans support a model of economic development in which man is the protagonist and counts more than a mushroom, because it generates value and also generates capacity for climate protection, we make industrial objectives as binding as those, and this will be an act. of great sincerity and honesty, industrial and cultural.

name: Martina WERNER
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. - Madam President, Commissioner, colleagues! Up until now, I have always had the feeling that we have always talked past each other in our dialogue with the European Commission. For me, industrial policy is not about listing everything that directly or indirectly influences industrial development. Instead, an EU industrial strategy should define goals and name measures how they can be achieved. The Commission's mainstream approach is reaching its limits at a time when challenges are putting the stability of European industry to the test. These are the enormous international competitive pressure and digitization. When we talk about industrial policy, however, we also have to keep two dimensions in mind - the external and the internal. In the first case, we need to dovetail industrial policy much more closely with trade policy. The Americans benefit from the exchange with the EU - Trump will understand that at some point - and the Chinese are still dependent on foreign know-how. We should use these levers. We have to take the Chinese rhetoric of free trade at its word and push for reciprocal market access and the protection of intellectual property. When we look at Europe, it is particularly important to me that competition, environmental, social and trade policies are more closely intertwined. A stronger interlinking of political areas also means that we have to pay much more attention to social acceptance, and that can only be achieved in a dialogue with trade unions and employers. In Germany, for example, the Future of Industry Alliance is working successfully, and I am sure that there are similar forums in other Member States. An industrial strategy can emerge from a European dialogue that sensibly combines cross-industry and sectoral elements. you must find answers to questions: How do we keep value creation and know-how in Europe, and which future fields are actually decisive?And only then does it make sense to adapt the legal framework or, for example, define the priorities for research and infrastructure funding after 2020.So now is the right time to reflect on industrial policy and for the Commission to finally come up with a proposal on it.

name: Evžen TOŠENOVSKÝ
text: for the ECR Group. - Madam President, in a globalized world, it is very important to keep our industry competitive. The EU needs a strategic approach to industrial policy, and in this sense we are also interested in what it has accomplished and what the European Commission is working on. Above all, however, the EU needs a sensible approach in the wider context of European policies. With ever-increasing restrictions, whether based on emission reductions and other social protection standards or regulations, there are, of course, fixed costs compared to countries where the rules are not as strict as in the EU. Returning to industrial policy in the narrower sense, it must be based on the promotion of research, the application of innovation as quickly as possible and the acceleration of the development of state-of-the-art technologies and their application in production itself. Unlocking the enormous potential in digital technologies, chemical research, high-tech engineering, nanotechnology and space technology gives hope for future industrial growth in EU Member States.

name: Enrique CALVET CHAMBON
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Your Excellency Madam Commissioner, Your Excellency Madam President. Let's see, finally, finally it seems that an industrial policy for Europe is being taken seriously. But, having said that, I must say with all due respect that I was a little disappointed by the position of the Commissioner. Again, we talk about innovation again. It's very good. Of course, who is not going to go for innovation? And, above all, linked to the environment. It's very good. Once again, we speak again, in the solutions, of the circular economy, which, of course, the ALDE Group supports, and so on. No, you see, that is still throwing balls out. Because we can say "look at what the United States innovates." Yes, but the United States has ten carriers cruising the world with the entire accompanying fleet. And there is not, there is no great economic complex that has its independence, its bargaining force, the prosperity and freedom of its people if it does not have a large industrial or military complex with research. And that's what we are talking about. And that's what Mr. Tajani talked about when he was Commissioner of Industry, of that 20%. What you have to do is take very seriously that freedom, prosperity, the future in independence or interdependence having a say in the world lies in having an industrial political source that manufactures things, not just that innovates. And that depends on whether the Commission takes it as a priority, the keyword of our question. As a priority, investing in rationalizing competition policy, investing in quality, stable employment with enormous added value. SMEs are going to benefit, because they live in perfect symbiosis with large companies and large industrial plans. Stability. We want stability. And, in the end, you have to explain to people that all that economic effort will be for their freedom, like, for example, Galileo.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Madam president. An ambitious industrial policy must necessarily be based on four aspects: public intervention, territorial cohesion, social rights and a new framework for global trade. Without regulation, the industry becomes the hostage of finance and rentiers, like the electricity oligopoly, pending only its benefits and not the productive development of the country. Therefore, the objective of 20% of industrial GDP cannot be achieved if these sectors are not put at the service of the general interest. Our organization advocates the nationalization of energy and banking, but even in the current framework we need reforms to lower industrial costs. Let's think about bilateral contracts between generators and industry or within industrial estates, possibilities very little exploited, for example, with governments of countries like Spain. We also need to fight against asymmetries within the European Union: while some countries accumulate trade surpluses, others have anemic industry, which prevents us from developing a productive model and condemns us to unemployment and precariousness. Only a true investment plan targeting less industrialized regions will ensure that they develop in the long term. Let's also talk about labor rights: industrial relocations, outsourcing and subcontracting are multiplying to weaken the labor movement. If we want a strong industry, we have to adapt the legislation to strengthen collective bargaining. If Europe wants to lead the industrial transition, it has to do so from productivity and not from precariousness. Finally, we need another view of global trade. It is up to this Parliament and the Council to decide whether to accept the unilateral liberalization of trade with China or whether they want to accelerate the destruction of industrial employment through trade agreements such as TTIP.We need new forms of global trade, rules that protect social and environmental standards and that fight against dumping.

name: Reinhard BÜTIKOFER
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! I am very happy about this discussion and would like to expressly thank the colleagues who initiated this. Ms. Bieńkowska, if you have listened carefully, there is one lesson you should learn from this discussion: stop patting yourself on the back as if you were doing everything right! At a time when a revolution is on the way, you have to show great design ambition if you don't want to end up in a dead end. I do not see this design ambition in you yet. I see six principles necessary for this industrial policy initiative at issue here. First: we need a European strategy, not just an agglomeration of national strategies. Second: innovation must be at the center. Everyone here says that. Thirdly: we need a cross-cutting policy instead of adding columnar attempts. Fourth, we need inclusivity, and inclusivity applies both to the workers that Mrs Werner spoke of and to the regions on which we are not allowed to depend. Fifth, we need a holistic approach, as Mrs Toia said. In my opinion, a holistic approach also means that we have to combine competitiveness and sustainability; this Parliament has already decided that. With you, Mrs Bieńkowska, the word does not even appear. The only time you ever go in that direction you talk about the climate, but only about the investment climate. There is a big hole in your vision! They don't even see what the basis for a successful European industrial policy of the future is, namely the combination of competitiveness and sustainability, the combination of digitization and eco-efficiency strategies. And sixth: We also need framework conditions. We got over that yesterday Foreign direct investment discussed in sensitive areas.We have to discuss competition law.It all belongs together - I'm looking forward to it.

name: Raymond FINCH
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, all the talk here has been about what the EU can and should do to enable growth, employment and innovation in Europe. I have an idea that to all of you might seem strange and against all precedent, but will, I think, work. Do nothing. In fact, stop what you are doing now. Roll it back. Let our nation-states do what they think is best for their peoples. Every nation is different, every nation has different strengths, circumstances and psyches. Your overarching one-size-fits-all strategies simply do not work and will only cause more hardship across our continent. Stop trying to harmonise everything. All your big plans do is give influence to the tens of thousands of lobbyists and their paymasters in tax-eating mega businesses and NGOs which infest your corridors of power and restrict innovation.  Let nations set their own tax rates. Let them do what they think best. Let national governments and their peoples again have the freedom they need to innovate and to create employment. This incessant desire to do something is actually a drag on innovation and employment. Do not follow the five-year plan mentality of social cooperative-style ideology. You cannot legislate yourselves into prosperity. Step back. Stop piling administrative burdens onto businesses and governments and let people work in their own enlightened economic self-interest. Innovation happens only when people have the freedom to innovate. Forcing people into your perception of what they should do is not only morally wrong: it is counterproductive. Resist the prescriptive urge. That is the only path to prosperity.  This constant desire to do something, anything, merely brings into existence a boa constrictor that chokes life and spirit from free peoples. Resist it. Let small businesses breathe. Take your fingers off your legislative trigger and burn some of the red tape you have already created. We will all be much happier for it. (The speaker declined to take a blue-card question from Massimiliano Salini)

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - Madam President, Commissioner Bieńkowska! The financial crisis showed us that a strong real economy and a strong industrial base are essential to create growth and employment. Countries with a strong industrial base have overcome the crisis much faster than others, which is why it is all the more important to develop an ambitious and forward-looking industrial strategy, an industrial strategy that specifies medium and long-term goals and an action plan with measures such as these goals can be implemented. This requires the Commission to work together with the Member States, because many of the factors that affect the competitiveness and sustainability of industrial workers are the same. These are too few investments, difficulties in accessing finance and markets, high energy prices, high administrative and administrative effort and, now more than ever before, especially in the area of ​​digitization, a lack of training content. The member states are particularly challenged to provide the tax framework for companies, to reduce administrative hurdles with modern corporate taxation, to invest in research and development and to promote the expansion of the transport, energy and communication infrastructure - especially the digital infrastructure for Industry 4.0 - to implement structural reforms and to pursue responsible budgetary policies. The Commission has a very important role, particularly with regard to access to financing options, in addition to bank financing, access to non-bank financing - “Capital Markets Union” is the keyword. In trade policy too - as has already been mentioned - it is essential to see this European trade strategy in a global context and also to see European companies Securing access, guaranteeing the supply of raw materials - as well as a joint climate and energy strategy and a digital strategy.If we want to achieve the target of 20% of industrial GDP, or perhaps more than 20%, as you said, Commissioner - very welcome.But then there has to be this common effort, then we need this common industrial strategy, and then everyone - the Commission, the Council and also Parliament - must pull together.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI). - Madam President, unfortunately industrial production in the Union is constantly declining. Especially in some countries there has been an almost complete disappearance of industrial activity. In Greece, the Commission is actively involved in enforcing a suffocating tax and insurance framework, which is destroying both commercial enterprises and industries and crafts. Through the agreements promoted by the Union with duty-free imports and free trade from third countries, it gives the final blow to an already wounded sector of the economy, which can create massive jobs, while workers' rights are relatively easier to safeguard. in large industries compared to small and difficult to control enterprises. Also, with the devaluation of industrial production, the research and development of new technologies is endangered. An immediate change in the Union's policy is needed in order to create a fair economic and fiscal background for the industries, which can and must be the locomotive of growth. At the same time, the protection of workers' rights and the environment must be ensured by industry.

name: Herbert REUL
text: - Madam President, Commissioner! Industry is important to the prosperity and wellbeing of the people in Europe. Obviously it's not going well - that's the stock. The industrial share in the world is falling, the European share is decreasing. So something has to be done. Therefore, everything cannot have been right. And now there is an argument about what is right. Some say: another dialogue, another conversation; some have even said: more laws; others said: more money. I think this is all wrong. I believe - some colleagues have also said this here - that industry in Europe has a chance if we help where we can, but also give industry the opportunity to let itself develop. The key is innovation - of course! What do we do at Horizon? We cut. Great, great contribution. Implementing structural reforms in the countries: The member states are responsible for this. Wherever Member States are not making good progress, we help, we apply pressure - half-heartedly. Half-heartedly - the Commission does not always take the opportunities that are available. Promote trade, promote international trade relations: We argue about whether CETA is right, whether TTIP is right - half of the event here in the hall doesn't want that at all. Yes, and then the question arises: does the industry, do the companies also have leeway where they can develop, of course within the given regulations? And there we happily decide to continue regulation. The truth is: we resolve a large part of the stresses that European industry has to endure when you look at the whole area of ​​industry, climate protection, energy policy and other things. And that doesn't make sense like that. It's not about the principle, it's about the extent. And we exaggerate excessively. (The speaker agrees to a question about the procedure the "blue card" under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Reinhard BÜTIKOFER
text: Ask about the “blue card” procedure.- Mr Reul!Since you have just criticized so sharply that we are constantly piling burdens on industry, I would ask you to list: What burdens has this Parliament decided on the initiative of the Juncker Commission since 2014 that you criticize so harshly?

name: Herbert REUL
text: Answer to a question about the “blue card” procedure.- With pleasure.You know that I believe that emissions trading is being exaggerated.We tried to make corrections in Parliament.I'm curious what will come of it.You and your parliamentary group are easy going to have ever higher demands in terms of energy efficiency and higher proportions of renewable energies.That drives up costs.These are just two small examples that I will give.I have a few more, but I'm not allowed to talk any longer.

name: Edouard MARTIN
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, happy to see you again, I was worried, I even almost launched a kidnapping alert, because you are the absent subscribers. Since your hearing in 2014, you have announced that you want to reduce the weight of industry to 20% of European GDP, you want to become leader again in a number of segments, etc. Of course, you have skilfully surfed the legacy of your predecessors, I am thinking in particular of Galileo, but what have you committed yourself? The account is not there. It is therefore high time that you put on the table a roadmap to achieve the goal that we have collectively set for ourselves. It can't be limited to hosting high-level meetings or other pinch-knuckles, it does nothing to advance the cause. Nor can this roadmap be the simple addition of sectoral policies that you regularly praise, but whose levers very often escape you. We need a real strategy to give a future to European industry. We socialists decline it under three aspects. First, a sustainable industry. It is not enough to boast of COP21. We can maintain industrial activity, including heavy ones, on European territory, provided that sustainability is made the first element of competitiveness. The force-feeding of CO2 quotas, unfortunately, promotes non-investment. Policies like the circular economy must also be accelerated. You mentioned it, we are waiting for action. Then, fair competition internationally. This affects both international trade, what some call intelligent protectionism or, at least, the end of European naivety (I am thinking in particular of the Chinese example), the right to competition and the reassessment of the market. relevant market, taking into account the reality of globalization and greater flexibility regarding the emergence of European champions.Finally, we need an industry rich in its knowledge and respectful of social dialogue.There can be no European industry without well-trained workers, properly protected against the vagaries of an increasingly financialized economy and able to fully play their role, as good connoisseurs of their work tools, in good management.and the strategic decisions of their business.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: - In fact, I think the issue is important enough and varies from country to country - less important for some countries and more important for others, but it needs to address the issues that are long overdue today, especially in countries with low employment and low incomes..Not only must they create jobs, but those jobs must be paid fairly normally.Otherwise, we will not resolve the difference between regions in individual countries and the differences between countries in Europe.If we do not address these issues together, we will not manage migration processes, both internal migration processes and external migration processes.And I see another tool: to involve local authorities more, namely in industrial development, and to link the benefits that industry receives so that it also benefits local government, the local people, so that they are interested.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: - Madam President, the Member States of the Union have been deindustrialising for more than 20 years. For states belonging to the euro zone, with the exception of Germany, where the euro is strong and maintained, deindustrialisation is proceeding even faster. The European doctrine of the knowledge economy has contributed since the early 2000s to the loss of competitiveness of our industries vis-à-vis emerging countries. The Union has failed to innovate, falling behind Asian countries and the United States for lack of sufficient investment. It has not been able to protect itself from competition from regions that do not have our social standards. These are the real reasons for gradual relocations, sometimes even when factories are doing well. It is no coincidence that the share of European industry in world GDP has fallen from 30.4% in 2008 to 23.8% today. The declarations of intent of the European Commission in the face of this reality seem to be stamped with hypocrisy and incompetence. The postponement to 2030 of the goal of increasing the share of industry in the Union's GDP to 20% by 2020 is proof of this. The Commission seeks to calm the anger due to the multiple closings of factories and the dismantling of entire sections of our industry, while it is largely responsible for the total lack of control and globalization, by tirelessly rehashing the idea of free competition while our competitors develop protective systems. The Alstom and Caterpillar cases illustrate in an exemplary manner the mistakes of a European economy incapable of setting a strategy and defending itself. Why continue to endorse policies that ruin us? It is time that we regain control over our destiny and our instruments of sovereignty. Do you want to be ambitious? So have the courage to give up your ideals and, finally, stand up for our industry. It is now that it must be done.After, it will be too late.

name: Anne SANDER
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, we know that the industrial policy of the European Union has never been truly ambitious. By favoring services to the detriment of industry, we have left aside entire sections of our economy, which led to the loss of 3.5 million industrial jobs between 2008 and 2014. This lack of strategy poses challenges. major problems of employment, innovation, as well as social and territorial cohesion. Today, beyond sectoral approaches, we need a framework, a vision, a medium and long-term roadmap. We absolutely need a coherent link between trade, environment, energy, investment, competition and employment policies. Europe has significant industrial strengths, with world leaders in the fields of pharmaceuticals, automobiles, chemicals, steel and rail. Don't let our competitors get behind us by being too naive or too timid.

name: Bernd LANGE
text: - Madam President! Commissioner, we have asked you five relatively specific questions. But I haven't heard any answers. The most common thing you said in your speech is “one should” or “we should” and that is not an answer to a question - because we do, in fact, expect us to respond to developments. If you look at it: there is an express train, driven by globalization, driven by digitalization, and we look at what the old steam locomotive is doing and try to turn one or the other adjusting screw. That is no solution! As Mrs Toia said, we need an integrated strategy within the EU and within the various sectors. That is why we need answers to the question of how you want to keep the innovation lead, how you want to ensure the participation of employees, how you want to ensure that the European share in global value chains is strengthened. So not “you have to”, but “when?” And “what?”!

name: Markus PIEPER
text: - Madam President! The orders from industry and their exports bring income to the region. This creates jobs and purchasing power, this creates tax revenue, and we use it to finance social achievements. That is part of social Europe - arguably the most important part. We should therefore guard the industry as we take the apple of our eye and warning signs seriously. First: Investments in energy-intensive companies in Germany are lower than depreciation - that is creeping de-industrialization. We are climate and environmental champions - if we turn this screw further, other regions do our business. The losers are the climate and jobs. That is why our climate policy must finally focus on the competitiveness of the economy again. Second: The big data companies do not come from Europe - from the automotive industry to shopfitting. But those who know the data on customer behavior today will determine the products of tomorrow. That is why we have to rely on digitization and broadband. That is why data is more of a raw material than a source of danger. Our politics must be more aware of this.

name: Pilar del CASTILLO VERA
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, today is a day in which we demonstrate the path on which the European Union must move forward. The path of concrete achievements. I insist, the path of concrete achievements. Like the end of roaming, which started today. A concrete achievement that benefits more than half a billion people and the entire European industry, especially small and medium-sized enterprises, and that represents an important step in the development of the digital single market. The competitiveness of European industry needs to advance along this path of concrete achievements. And in that direction, it is urgent to have the infrastructures of fixed and broadband networks to develop the best connectivity, which in turn allows to develop 5G and, with it, to have an instrument for European industry to benefit from digital technologies like the internet of things, which constitute an extraordinary opportunity for the global competitiveness of the manufacturing industry.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: - Commissioner, I listened very carefully to your speech and I must say that I was also disappointed. After three years of the Commission working, saying only general sentences will not, in my view, help European industry much. Like some of my colleagues, I think that better conditions need to be created for European industry, but that this is certainly not the way of regulation. On the contrary, breaking down regulations is what needs to be done by the European Commission. The internal market needs to be improved and enhanced. The digital agenda has been mentioned many times. If, at least in this area, concrete steps were taken during this legislature, then it would certainly help the industry. It is certainly necessary to talk about specific investments in innovation and research, which is also an important thing. I would also like to mention, in the short time I have, the European Union's international trade policy. Free trade agreements help a lot, and we were able to see this, for example, in the agreement with South Korea, which we recently evaluated.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, I listened to Mr Reul’s answer to the question by Mr Bütikofer and I think it made sense, because there is a tendency – especially in this mandate – for Parliament, whenever the Commission makes a proposal, to have to change it, be it good or bad. We have to go either above or below what the Commission says. Sometimes this does not make sense, and I think we have to look at it, especially if we want to grow industry in Europe, to do what is practical, and not to be overburdening them with all sorts of regulations, etc., that are unnecessary. The second point I would make is that talent is vital as well. Recently, BorgWarner in the town where I live, close to Tralee in Ireland, expanded. They said that the reason they did so was that the local institute of technology (IT) was producing the talent they needed. We have to support the ITs in particular, in order to bring the talent that is needed for the industries of the future.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the European Union must equip itself with an industrial policy strategy capable of protecting the interests of the Member States, a strategy geared towards maintaining the competitiveness of European industry globally. The Commission has repeatedly underlined the objective of bringing the share of industry in the European Union's GDP back to 20% by 2020, a goal that is difficult to achieve if we do not put in greater ambition by focusing more on innovation and sustainability. A holistic industrial policy strategy is needed, capable of guiding industrial policy by integrating the 20% GDP target with the climate and energy targets for 2030. The green economy is the path to the new industrial revolution. Only if we have the courage and the ability to bet seriously will we determine a competitive advantage for our system. The action must be focused on small and medium-sized enterprises, favoring productive collaboration through the intelligent management of distribution channels, the integrated management of networked logistics and the interoperability of information systems.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI). - Madam President, the development of industry is based on its ability to adapt and innovate. But the lack of an EU strategy and misguided tax policies have had disastrous results. The reduction in production costs was not based on improving energy and technological efficiency, but shifted to a corresponding reduction in wage costs and pension contributions. The lack of adequate access to adequate funding and the failure to reduce bureaucracy and administrative formalities overburden small and medium-sized industrial enterprises and force them to evade taxes. The pursuit of high specialization has been abandoned. The interconnectedness of the research community with industry is constantly weakening, while measures against unfair commercial practices and the lack of strategic autonomy in key areas such as defense are indulgently inadequate. The development of industry is not achieved through globalization and free trade. It is achieved through the practical support of industrial enterprises, the reduction of bureaucratic difficulties and the connectivity of industry with other areas of research and technology.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Madam President, I believe that it is essential for  the Commission to outline what concrete results have been achieved by mainstreaming industrial competitiveness into EU policy. In the light of, on the one hand, the decline in the role of industry in the overall economy  and, on the other hand, of the critical challenges facing Europe, we should be aware of the Commission’s possible reactions and know what action will it take to deal with the factors impacting the global competitiveness of European Union industry. I believe that the Commission should respond to the calls to provide an assessment of the impact of mainstreaming industrial policy into the EU strategic initiatives and to submit a holistic EU industrial policy strategy together with a corresponding action plan. This is a must, Commissioner, and it should include an initiative in the Commission’s 2018 work programme.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, first I would like to thank you for this discussion. I think that, for me especially, it was very valuable. I share most of your views. I also think that the time has come that we need a holistic, as you call it, coherent European industrial strategy. But what I cannot agree with is that we have in a way – of course nobody has said it – that we have wasted these two and a half years. I will still defend our approach so far. With our communication on smart industry, on clean industry, in our work on the circular economy, with mainstreaming industrial policy through all of our documents and our projects, with our Industry Day which I want to repeat every year, I think we have a very good base now to have the coherent strategy. I also agree that it is quite difficult, much more difficult, to use existing instruments if we do not have such a common approach, but definitely those two and a half years were not wasted. We are prepared quite well, but we need the support of everyone and every actor to have and to start the work on such a strategy.  I also want to assure you, and especially Mr Martin – I am happy that I made you happy – that I have not disappeared. I have prepared two major industrial strategies: the space strategy that was adopted last December and the European defence action plan with very concrete actions, very concrete money and a very detailed programme for European industry in this sector. In addition of course, to all of our activities in the single market strategy: services package, goods package, compliance package and public procurement. So I can assure you that with this portfolio I will not be able to disappear!

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: The debate is closed.The motions for resolutions to be tabled under Rule 128 (5) will be announced at a later date.The vote will take place during the next part-session.Written statements (Rule 162)

name: András GYÜRK
text: in writing. - There are trendy policy topics that are talked about a lot. My impression is that the common European industrial strategy is not one of them. While the stakes are high: jobs, knowledge and tradition. There is no question that the key to the success of European industry is quality, excellent value for money. It is therefore worth focusing on two pillars: innovation and competitive pricing. First, appropriate regulation should help increase R&D spending in a technology-neutral way. Second, we need to give all the help we need to the industry so that they can sell their products at a competitive price in the global market as well. For energy-intensive industries, the level of energy prices is crucial. With the creation of the single energy market, we have started to reduce energy prices. However, there are still some pending energy policy issues that could negatively affect market development. An excellent example of this is the authorization of the expansion of the Nord Stream gas pipeline, which could contribute to rising energy prices in some Member States. I would like to draw the Commission's attention to the priority given to these aspects - innovation and competitive energy prices - in the further development of the industrial strategy.

name: Carolina PUNSET
text: written. - The modernization of the industry must assume the climatic commitments. Today, no industrial technique can be developed that does not seek to satisfy the needs of citizens, such as well-being or employment, but, above all, industrial policy must be in tune with the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions in all the production process, from innovation to distribution. The population demands more and more elements of consumption that respect the environment and the development of the green economy is an opportunity that Europe must not reject. In the impact evaluations of the European Commission on the development of the renewable energy generation industry and on the improvements of the construction sector in energy efficiency, it is estimated, among other estimates, that more than 800,000 jobs will be created in both industrial sectors. Despite the legislative obstacles, we know that countries such as Denmark or Spain are world leaders in the development of wind turbines. The decarbonisation of the economy, increasingly demanded by consumers, is an opportunity for European industry: we must see it as an opportunity to produce, in clear distinction from other economies that are not committed to the future.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: The next item is the debate on six motions for resolutions on the case of Azerbaijani journalist Äfqan Muxtarlı (2017/2722 (RSP)).

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: author. – Madam President, the alleged abduction of Azerbaijani citizen Afgan Mukhtarli on Georgian soil is an extremely concerning and serious case, particularly given his background as a journalist who has fled there in search of a safe haven from persecution by the Azerbaijani authorities. Allegations that the Georgian security services may have in some way been complicit with these events is also of deep concern, and I welcome the calls in the resolution today for a full investigation of these claims.  Investigative journalism that seeks to uncover corruption and abuses of justice is vital in all countries, but especially so in countries such as Azerbaijan, which are marked by distinct deficiencies in the democratic processes and the rule of law. Incidents such as this undermine the efforts to encourage journalists such as Mukhtarli to continue their work in freedom, and to believe that sanctuary can be found if necessary. I hope, as investigations into the affair proceed, that we will at the very least see the release of Mukhtarli, and that all charges filed by the Azerbaijani authorities against him in this regard are dropped.

name: Rebecca HARMS
text: Author. - Madam President, dear colleagues! Mr Tannock described the situation very well. The most frightening thing about the journalist Äfqan Muxtarlı's case is that the unjust justice system obviously not only works in Azerbaijan, but that the arm extends from Azerbaijan to Georgia. And it is very important to us that this case as a whole is cleared up and that independent investigations into it take place not only in Azerbaijan, but also in Georgia. I very much hope that our resolution can help Äfqan Muxtarlı. I am counting on Commissioner Hahn, who will be in Baku tomorrow, to negotiate on this. And I hope that all other cases of unjust justice will also be an issue for relations between the European institutions and Azerbaijan. Our resolution calls for the immediate release not only of Äfqan Muxtarlı, but of dozens of other journalists and human rights defenders who are unjustly imprisoned in Azerbaijan and who are also being tortured.

name: Soraya POST
text: author. – Madam President, on 29 May 2017 the Azerbaijani journalist Afgan Mukhtarli disappeared from his exile in Tbilisi, Georgia. He was abducted and, according to his own account, beaten up and thrown into a car. The next day he was in Baku, Azerbaijan. Mukhtarli has since then been sentenced to prison. We are happy that the European Union has a broad cooperation with Azerbaijan, and we would like to deepen that. But let us be very clear that to breach the sovereignty of other countries to abduct, beat up and imprison journalists and critics of the government is completely unacceptable. We utterly condemn what has happened to Mr Mukhtarli and call on the Georgian Government to ensure a prompt investigation. We call on the Azerbaijani Government to immediately drop all the bogus charges against Afgan Mukhtarli and release him from prison and, with him, let all the political prisoners go.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: author. – Madam President, we all – and people of Azerbaijan in particular – need a democracy and value-based partnership, but not an illusion of it. Only full respect of basic freedoms and the rule of law will enable us to build solid and lasting political and trade relations. Otherwise, this partnership will be simply doomed, as it proved to be in the cases of Russia and Turkey, among others.  Therefore, the abducted journalist Afgan Mukhtarli must be immediately released and officially pardoned by Baku. Prompt and transparent investigation must be conducted in both Georgia and Azerbaijan.  Finally, the release and rehabilitation of all political prisoners must be at the core of the partnership agreement. This is where the EU must stand firm. Today, we have to repeat it once again: Baku and Tbilisi must be partners in the investigation, and we have to receive all and final information on this case, otherwise there are many doubts about future partnerships.

name: Helmut SCHOLZ
text: Author. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen! I would like to expressly agree to postponing the vote on the resolution on the Äfqan Muxtarlı case as it is being discussed. As so often, we practice the balancing act between the expectations of someone who has been injured in his rights and the search for a suitable way to help universal rights to breakthrough. The dialogue - regardless of the level at which it is conducted - is a thousand times better than an essentially speechless confrontation. A few days ago in the southern Caucasus I was able to observe for myself how complex the social transformation processes are in the region, how great is the need for joint social learning processes and meeting processes. The human rights demands of our resolution are clearly placed here. Äfqan Muxtarlı is to be released immediately, and the charges against him are to be overturned, because in the end nowhere can justice be pronounced which is based on a fundamental injustice. The obvious kidnapping of someone who has fled persecution and his transfer to the country he fled from is wrong. Our demand also applies: the country that pretended to be a safe place of escape must prove without contradiction that it has nothing to do with the kidnapping. Azerbaijan has developed inconsistently in terms of human rights. We learn again from this that our demands can only be implemented sustainably if something changes in the systems of exercise of power. The criminalization of criticism and critics will go on and on if it is not ultimately made a criminal offense and prosecution itself. Equality of arms in conflicts between the state and the individual cannot exist unless this is guaranteed by law. We are already in the intensive preparation phase for the next summit on the Eastern Neighborhood. I want the Commission in context give this discussion a chance to reflect on how the EU can further develop its corresponding instruments.The European Parliament is interested in producing fewer Thursday resolutions and much more in achieving real changes in our partner countries.

name: Željana ZOVKO
text: author. – Madam President, the joint motion for a resolution relates to the case of the Azerbaijani journalist Afgan Mukhtarli, who was subjected to forced disappearance in Georgia, resurfaced in Baku a few hours later, and ended up in prison. We spoke to his wife this morning. The text produced by several groups is a solid one and critical of Azerbaijan as well as Georgia. As regards Azerbaijan we criticise the human rights situation and the ongoing crackdown on NGOs, human rights activists and journalists. We demand the immediate release of Mr Mukhtarli as well.  However, we have been requested by Commissioner Hahn to postpone the vote on the resolution. He will be in Baku on Friday. The adoption of the resolution, as he said, will make his mission virtually impossible. As saving face is usually very important for the Azerbaijani side, the Commissioner might encounter additional difficulties in Baku. Indeed, postponing the vote could serve as additional leverage for the Commission.  I strongly support postponing the vote and silent diplomacy instead of having this resolution adopted today.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Madam President, I condemn, like my colleagues, the kidnapping and detention of journalist Afgan Mukhtarli, it is an attack on the freedom of the press which is, as we know, a non-negotiable value for us. I therefore call for the immediate release of Afgan Mukhtarli and for a full and honest investigation into his kidnapping, both in Azerbaijan and in Georgia. In February, when President Ilham Aliev came to Brussels, we showed our openness to strengthen cooperation with Azerbaijan in various fields, ranging from energy to trade, but also to discuss more often the basis on which this cooperation must be built: respect for fundamental freedoms. I therefore invite our Azerbaijani partners to discuss with us openly, especially in the framework of our parliamentary cooperation, the best ways to implement these values, the only ones on which prosperity and stability can be based. I am sure that Commissioner Hahn's presence in Baku next week will send the same message: our willingness to cooperate, but also the importance we place on the values ​​of freedom.

name: Kati PIRI
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - Being kidnapped in broad daylight in Tiblisi, the Georgian capital, suddenly finding yourself on the Azerbaijani border and waking up the next day in a prison cell. It happened to investigative journalist Afgan Mukhtarli, who was arrested 2 weeks ago under false pretenses and now has the prospect of a long-term politically motivated trial in Azerbaijan. The situation is part of a series of worrying developments, with the Baku government silencing critics, from fabricated crimes to oppressive legislation and bureaucratic rules for civil society organizations. The result? Today, more than 100 political prisoners are held without the prospect of anything resembling a fair trial. But the repression has now entered a new phase. Political refugees in neighboring countries are apparently no longer safe either. According to Mukhtarli, his captors spoke Georgian. This raises serious questions about the possible involvement of the Georgian security services. Therefore, this must also be researched to the bottom. It means that hundreds of Azerbaijanis living in exile in Georgia suddenly have to worry about their safety. Let me say the last words in English so that we can have the debate here in the Parliament. There is this proposal to postpone, for the first time, a vote on a matter of urgency. I think the word "urgency" says it all: we are talking here about an individual human rights case, and this Parliament should not postpone a vote on such a severe situation, because it will set a precedent which we should not want. I hope today we can go to a vote on a very good resolution which has been negotiated. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162 (8))

name: Reinhard BÜTIKOFER
text: Ask about the “blue card” procedure.- Mrs Piri!Would you also make the same proposal if Commissioner Hahn were a social democrat?

name: Kati PIRI
text: blue-card answer. – I’m sorry, but I think this is a very crazy question: we don’t make judgments about who does the request. We make judgments on the case itself. All the groups were in favour of having this resolution because of its seriousness. All the groups negotiated a request. This is not a political colour question, and I find your question, to be honest, actually very disgraceful.

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, as a friend of both Georgia and Azerbaijan, I am most concerned by the case of Afgan Mukhtarli. His abduction, allegedly by Georgian services, is a serious blow to the reputation of that country. The triggering mechanism and unfortunate violent finish was somewhere in Azerbaijan. The investigation, as energetic as possible, should be carried out in both countries, and we have to support the silent diplomacy of Commissioner Hahn, postponing the vote on the resolution.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, we all agree on the substance of the evaluation, so where we differ on is what the best approach is in order to release Mr Mukhtarli. Now the question is […]  Colleagues, I listened to you; Mr Bütikofer, it is not easy if you are shouting a few metres away from me. I do apologise, Madam President.  Once again, we differ on how to proceed, and what the best tactics are. If we were dealing with a different government with a different regime, I could understand the appeal of Mr Hahn, but the abduction happened a few days after a European Parliament high—ranking delegation spoke for an hour and a half with the President of the country, Mr Aliyev – so that is the message. The other message would be that if we postpone it today and Mr Hahn goes, what is the message that we are sending? For the first time, we have postponed an urgency resolution, and we are not united. I disagree with Mr Hahn, because I think that he can go to Baku and have behind him a resolution which puts pressure on him. For me, in that current situation with this regime, with the disrespect to Parliament that Mr Aliyev has shown, it is the only possible way.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, however we are going to decide on this, it is clear that this is an unforeseen, unprecedented case. Two friendly countries, two EU eastern neighbours, and what happened was that there was a reported abduction from the territory of an independent country. I fully see why the President Margvelashvili of Georgia has said that this is not only a question of upholding human rights and freedom of the media, but it is also about defending Georgian statehood. That is why we all have reason to believe that Georgia is conducting a totally transparent and independent investigation into what happened. We are faced with two completely different stories on what happened and we need to get this right, because this should never happen again.  The main thing is that, whatever we decide today about voting today or in three weeks’ time, the Commission has to do their utmost to get Mr Afgan Mukhtarli free.

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: - Madam President! Let us not argue in this House today about when we should vote on this resolution. Let us talk about freedom of speech, which is undoubtedly one of the most important values, extremely close to every European. Therefore, we should definitely oppose any form of violation. In particular, we do not agree to such brutal forms of suppression as is the case of Afghan Mukhtarli, who, being an independent journalist openly criticizing the actions of the Azerbaijani government, was kidnapped in Georgia, forcibly transported to Azerbaijan and arrested on dubious charges. It should also be emphasized that the case of A. Mukhtarli is not an isolated one. That is why I emphasize that there can be no consent from the European Union to political prisoners and we call on the Azerbaijani Government to release them. I believe that this postulate must also be one of the points of the partnership agreement between the EU and Azerbaijan, negotiated since February this year.

name: Kosma ZŁOTOWSKI
text: - Madam President! The arrest of Afghan Mukhtarli is an event of concern to all those who care about peace and stability in the South Caucasus region. If the doubts as to the place and course of his arrest and the charges against him are finally confirmed, it will certainly not be beneficial for strengthening mutual cooperation between the European Union, Azerbaijan and Georgia, whose services also seem to have played an infamous role in this matter. However, I am pleased that the joint text of the resolution also reveals what has been achieved recently, especially in terms of cooperation within the Euronest Parliamentary Assembly. Building a democratic state in such difficult geopolitical conditions is a huge challenge that many countries are struggling with in the post-Soviet area. There is no doubt that we must do more to support this process, also in the economic dimension. Coming back to the Afghan Mukhtarli case: if there is any chance of success for Commissioner Hahn's mission, we should postpone this vote.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: - Madam President, I am speaking in my capacity as Parliament's rapporteur for Azerbaijan. I have been following your position very closely, and one thing has caught my eye: many of you are speaking in the words "if these allegations were true, they could be complicit." I believe that a parliament has an obligation to rule by an emergency resolution on very clear issues. There are currently two investigations: one in Baku and one in Tbilisi. If we all know very well that Azerbaijan is not a country that performs in protecting human rights, I don't think anyone in this room has any doubts about Georgia. I believe that Commissioner Hahn's approach is legitimate, fair and coherent in terms of Eastern Partnership policy. We must first clarify a situation and then react with all the means that Parliament and the Union have. Starting from such allegations, we risk straining relations in the area. It is very important for me to have a solid and serious approach and to postpone this vote, after we have a very clear perception of the Commission.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: – Madam President, dear colleagues, two weeks ago an official delegation of the Committee on Foreign Affairs (AFET), with seven Members, visited Azerbaijan, Armenia and Georgia. We met the highest State representatives from civil society and diplomacy. After a long period of interrupted dialogue with Baku, caused by over-sensitive reactions to a similar urgency resolution some years ago, we received assurances of a strong interest in closer cooperation based upon common strategic interests and values. The delegation paid a visit to two places which symbolised the complexity of history and the present day: a camp for refugees from occupied Nagorno Karabakh near Baku, and an Armenian memorial for genocide in Yerevan. The EU is offering to all countries of the Caucasus a partnership based upon human rights, the rule of law and freedom of expression. This means that one single journalist or human rights defender in jail is one too many. Negotiations with Azerbaijan on the comprehensive Partnership Agreement has been started. Open issues from these resolutions should be dealt with in this framework. I believe in active politics and diplomacy, therefore I cannot support this resolution, which still has too many question marks.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: - Madam President, on 29 May, the journalist Afgan Mukhtarli was kidnapped by unidentified men who allegedly wore Georgian Judiciary Police uniforms, only to later be released into the hands of the Azerbaijani authorities. Afgan Mukhtarli was beaten and driven to the Azerbaijan border with a hefty sum of money, with the sole purpose of allowing the Azerbaijani authorities to institute criminal proceedings for illegal crossing of the border and for smuggling. The evidence was manipulated to allow him to be detained and sentenced to several years' imprisonment. The truth, ladies and gentlemen, is that this practice of intimidation, repression and persecution is repeatedly applied in Azerbaijan to leaders of non-governmental organizations, human rights defenders, members of the opposition and journalists. At a time when negotiations are underway to implement the new partnership between the European Union and Azerbaijan, the European Parliament must unequivocally condemn the arbitrary arrest of journalist Afgan Mukhtarli and demand his immediate release. I believe that the European Union cannot agree to regimes that shamelessly and repeatedly disrespect human rights and fundamental freedoms and must do everything to ensure that violations of international law are properly sanctioned.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, of course, a situation has been debated here, as our colleague Norica Nicolai said, in which we do not have all the relevant data.I think we need to be a responsible Parliament.I am also a member of the Euronest Parliamentary Assembly.We know the problems in Azerbaijan and other countries.We know that Azerbaijan is important in Euronest and has an agenda related to the European Union, but I also believe that we need to postpone this resolution, in order to document ourselves and come up with extremely precise things.It is, of course, about a man's life.It's about freedom of the press.At the same time, we have to have all the arguments before we make decisions, and that is my point of view.(The speaker agreed to answer a question put under the 'blue card' procedure (Rule 149 (8)))

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: blue-card question. – I would like to ask my good colleague, Maria Grapini, whether she would look into the resolution again, because it’s precisely asking for an investigation. So it’s not that we want to postpone the investigation; we want to have a serious, independent, transparent investigation on what actually happened, and this is the point in the resolution. Both sides of the border.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: answer to a question addressed in accordance with the "blue card" procedure.- I understood my colleague's question and I really appreciate it.By the way, I have all the appreciation for our colleague.I know his work in Parliament and in committee.Yes, of course, I read the resolution.I was just saying that it is not that a resolution is not needed, but that, from my point of view, it is hasty to make a resolution so quickly, without waiting, as the commissioner said, for more in-depth documentation.Not that there's no need.I argue that we need a resolution for Azerbaijan, but not now.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Afgan Mukhtarli was walking quietly through the streets of Tbilisi on 29 May, after an evening with his colleagues, until some men in a Georgian criminal police uniform stop him, hood him, push him into the car , they beat him and deposit him over the border with Azerbaijan, with 10 000 euros in his pocket. Now Afgan is in Baku, in custody of the border police, and charges of smuggling, illegal border crossing and violence against the police authorities hang before him. Afgan is a brave investigative journalist as his wife. He had already fled to Georgia in 2015, fearing for his own safety, while continuing to investigate the holdings of the Azerbaijani President Aliyev's family, and it is known that those who want to snoop too much into the Azerbaijani President's affairs never have an easy life in his country. he. The question is: how can one disappear in Tbilisi and find oneself in Baku? We are calling for a quick and transparent investigation, but we cannot accept that Azerbaijan on the other side always takes one step forward and two steps back. Political prisoners must be released, journalists must be stopped ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: - I very much appreciate the EP's systematic commitment to respecting the human rights of the Eastern Partnership countries.This resolution of ours responds to specific information about the abduction of Afghan Muchtarli from Tbilisi to Baku, where he is being held.The real reason for his imprisonment is that he worked in an independent medium - Radio Free Europe - and is known as a critic of the Azerbaijani regime.Unfortunately, there are more such political prisoners in Azerbaijan, and our resolution mentions them, listing them all.The EP calls for their release, including journalists.This latest case of an arrested journalist is strongly reminiscent of the dictatorial practices we know well from communist regimes.That is why I support the EP's position that the release of political prisoners, journalists and an end to their persecution should be a clear condition for a further agreement between the EU and Azerbaijan.I particularly appreciate the political agreement on this resolution.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, the disregard for the fundamental right of freedom of expression demonstrated by the Azerbaijani Government, as evidenced in the case of Afgan Mukhtarli, is an issue of great concern to both my colleagues and me in the European Parliament, as is evidenced by this resolution and the speeches made by colleagues here this morning. Afgan Mukhtarli’s abduction and imprisonment is a clear violation of international law, and it is crucial that the Azerbaijani Government be held accountable. The alleged involvement of Georgian officials in this case must also be scrutinised in terms of respect for fundamental rights and the integrity of government, especially as he fled there and finished up in Baku. That was some safe haven in Tbilisi. Looking forward, the safeguarding of freedom of the press and freedom of expression should be prioritised as a central facet to the future of EU—Azerbaijani relations.   Dá bhrí sin, a Uachtaráin, caithfimid gach iarracht a dhéanamh chun an sprioc sin a bhaint amach agus brú níos mó a chur ar rialtas na hAsarbaiseáine chun Mukhtarli a ligean saor láithreach bonn agus más féidir sin a dhéanamh, beidh jab maith déanta againn.

name: Ana GOMES
text: - Despite the release of human rights activists in Azerbaijan in the past two years, repression of independent media, attacks on freedom of expression have become increasingly brutal, including imprisonment, fabricated criminal charges, intimidating surveillance, torture and even death in state custody, as happened to blogger Mehman Huseynov last April. Also intolerable is the Azerbaijan government's refusal to comply with trials by the European Court of Human Rights. We strongly condemn the kidnapping of Afgan Mukhtarli in Georgia, his forced transfer to a prison in Azerbaijan. Whoever was involved in this kidnapping has to be investigated and brought to court in Georgia, a country that must accommodate all asylum seekers who escape political persecution in neighboring countries, such as Azerbaijan, Turkey or Russia. Afgan Mukhtarli and all other political prisoners must be released immediately in Azerbaijan and the pending charges must be dropped. I hope that Commissioner Johannes Hahn's steps in Baku will be attended to by the Azerbaijani government now, and not in months. Here, in this Parliament, there are many of us who do not exchange human rights for oil or for bribes from the kleptocracy that oppresses the people of Azerbaijan.

name: Ana GOMES
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, the EU observes attentively the narrowing of space for exercising fundamental freedoms in Azerbaijan. We have taken careful note of the arrest and sentencing of the number of persons who have criticised the authorities, as well as systemic measures to curb freedom of expression, such as a decision to permanently block five online media outlets or increase criminal penalties for insulting the President.  The number of government critics behind bars has increased rapidly since last summer. The charges are not always related to the exercise of freedom of expression, but range, of course, from drug-related charges to liberal and financial irregularities. What these cases have in common is the ease with which the arguments of the defence have been dismissed. On 30 May, the EU reacted immediately to the apparent abduction of a journalist in another country in order to imprison him in Azerbaijan, recalling that civil rights and due process of law must be respected.  These developments ran counter to the broader renewal of recent positive engagement between the EU and Azerbaijan following a number of positive developments since 2015, including the release of several high-profile human rights defenders, activists and journalists. Positive interparliamentary cooperation has also resumed and the visit by the Committee on Foreign Affairs to Azerbaijan in May was welcomed as a part of this renewed engagement. We will step up our diplomatic effort to return to this path. In a statement on 4 June, the spokesperson for the High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy/Vice-President of the Commission called for an immediate review of the case and the release of all individuals detained as a result of exercising their fundamental freedoms. The issue will also be raised by Commissioner Hahn, as you noticed, who will be visiting Baku as of tomorrow, including with President Aliyev. The EEAS has also raised this point in a meeting with their counterparts. Our main tool for steering our relationship with Azerbaijan is, of course, the new agreement that is currently being negotiated. The latest round took place earlier this week and human rights were again one of the main issues discussed. We will pursue relentlessly an agreement that puts respect for human rights at the core of our relationships.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: I close the debate.The vote will take place on Thursday 15 June 2017.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: The next item is the debate on six motions for resolutions on Pakistan, in particular the situation of human rights defenders and the application of the death penalty (2017/2723 (RSP)).

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: author. – Mr President, I am very glad that this debate is taking place. The situation regarding human rights in Pakistan is very difficult. Ethnic and religious minorities experience huge difficulties if they are different from – or think differently to – the government or the majority of the Pakistani people. Several minority people have been killed or persecuted because they were not protected by the government. One issue I want to highlight in particular is the so—called blasphemy laws. I would like to ask the High Commissioner to urge the Government of Pakistan to review these laws or, even better, to abolish them. These laws are wide open to misuse as tools for setting personal vendettas and oppressing minorities.
