The Pakistani Government therefore also should make sure that, until the laws are revised, people will not suffer as a result of them for false purposes.

name: Soraya POST
text: author. – Mr President, these days many of us have written something on social media that we have later come to regret. That can be a worry – not least if you are a politician. In some places, however, it can mean that you put your life at stake. A man has just been sentenced to death in Pakistan for insulting the prophet on Facebook. Of 50 Muslim-majority countries around the world, only 13 – including Pakistan – have a death penalty for blasphemy. Islam is a religion of peace, not of death. We welcome the Pakistani Government’s decision to adopt the Human Rights Action Plan; we call on them to repeal capital punishment for blasphemy and immediately release all prisoners held under these charges. Only a country that allows people to speak out freely can truly be called righteous.

name: Jozo RADOŠ
text: author.- Mr. President, the death penalty and the blasphemy law in Pakistan particularly affect, of course, journalists and human rights activists, as well as members of minorities.It is of particular concern that among the victims of such a policy and these provisions of the law in Pakistan are minors, therefore, minors.I would like to emphasize, draw attention and express concern about the pressure of the Pakistani authorities on Internet platforms, Facebook and Twitter, to reveal the identity of users of these platforms so that people can be persecuted for blasphemy and the possible threat of the death penalty.I welcome the adoption of the Human Rights Action Plan in Pakistan and I hope that this Action Plan will help to improve the human rights situation in Pakistan and address the issue of the death penalty and the blasphemy law.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: Author. - Mr President, since the tragic attack in December 2014, in which more than 100 people died - most of them boys and girls - the Government of Pakistan has activated the National Action Plan to combat terrorism. Among other things, this plan includes the execution of death sentences for those accused of terrorism. Unfortunately, we have seen how, within the umbrella of the accusation of terrorism, the Government of Pakistan is including all kinds of cases, especially to persecute the political and social opposition. Especially significant is the case of the activist Baba Jan and twelve other peaceful protesters, sentenced to life imprisonment in 2014 by the Anti-Terrorism Tribunal. From here we send you a big greeting and hug. This situation is a clear step back from the 2008 moratorium, which partially eased the execution of civilians. But since the beginning of 2015 this moratorium has completely ended for all those sentenced for capital crimes. From here we want to demand not only fair and fair trials and freedom for political activists unjustly imprisoned in Pakistan like Baba Jan, but we want to raise our voice for the global abolition of the death penalty. In our opinion, this situation shows, once again, the shame of a European Union and, in particular, of the Commission, which allows Pakistan to be one of the eight countries that benefit from the Generalized System of Preferences - the GSP -, for which is obtained preferential rates in exchange for the commitment to respect human rights, which Pakistan does not respect. To this day, the monitoring system and the SPG itself are clearly in question, once again. Surely, this system has contributed a lot to boost many businesses. We know, for example, that many European companies import manufactured textile products from Pakistan and surely benefit from this framework. What is intolerable is that in exchange for this, for these businesses, the Commission has looked the other way before the systematic violation of human rights in Pakistan.This can not go on like this.

name: Tunne KELAM
text: author. – Mr President, Pakistan is an important partner for the EU. However, this Parliament is seriously concerned about the human rights situation, especially about the number of executions after Pakistan reinstated the death penalty. Most alarming is the use, or rather misuse of the so-called blasphemy law, which carries a mandatory death penalty. On 10 June 2017, the Pakistani court passed a death sentence to Taimoor Raza for committing blasphemy on Facebook.  We call on the Pakistani authorities to introduce some immediate measures that could reverse this present trend, first on all executions on any offense other than intentional killing. Second, stop executing juvenile offenders. Third, provide a moratorium on executions on those whose appeals are pending. Fourth, reinstate a moratorium on all executions as soon as possible and provide also maximum state guarantees for normal work of journalists, NGOs and human rights defenders.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: for the PPE Group. - I want to strongly support this resolution, which criticizes the abuse of the death penalty in Pakistan. I am a lifelong opponent of the death penalty, and I am very pleased that the EU has this philosophy and criticizes the use and abuse of the death penalty in individual countries around the world. Not only that, Pakistan has withdrawn from the 2015 moratorium and is using the death penalty again. He originally wanted to use it only against the most serious punishments, such as terrorism, murder, etc., but my predecessors have already made it clear that at the moment this punishment is being abused, in principle for political acts such as blasphemy. In addition to the death penalty, the anti-blasphemy law, which has also been mentioned several times here, must be criticized. It is clearly aimed at the death penalty, against freedom of expression, freedom of speech, and we should make it clear to Pakistan that if it wants to be an EU partner and have a privileged position in the future, it cannot abuse the death penalty and bend human rights in its country. .

name: Neena GILL
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, in 2014 the EU allowed Pakistan access to GSP+, an exceptional tool to help kick-start the economy, and which, crucially, encourages progress on improving human rights. It has proved its value in many countries, but I question whether this is the case in Pakistan. A Parliament delegation visited Pakistan in April and, from our meetings with government officials and civil society, it became glaringly clear that a lack of the rule of law permeates Pakistani society, and human rights are violated instead of advanced. In March 2017, military courts that can try civilians were reinstated for two more years. The basic rights of foreigners brought to trial are trampled on, with no access to consular rights. People who work for NGOs face harassment, arrest or, worse, death. How many people are on death row under the vague blasphemy laws? We do not know, because there is no transparency. Anyone going about their business can be accused of blasphemy and then lynched by mobs. Those who belong to vulnerable groups like the Ahmadis live their lives in fear, with no democratic rights, yet the government fails to protect them. It is high time to see real progress on human rights and the strengthening of the civil judiciary in Pakistan. If not, GSP+ has to be reviewed.

name: Sajjad KARIM
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, our non-legislative and non—binding resolutions quite often lead to complaints from third countries of factual inaccuracies. Today, I intend to concentrate only on one aspect of what is in the resolution and do not in any way seek to take away from some of the very accurate comments that have been made by colleagues, whilst recognising that there are various inaccuracies as well.  Any consideration by an independent and informed eye of this resolution actually betrays an acceptance that external and externally sponsored internal actors in Pakistan are facilitating the terrorist targeting of innocent civilians. The people of Pakistan have carried a very heavy burden on behalf of the international community for a very long time – sometimes on very weak shoulders. But it remains the case that our EU policy to support Pakistan and the people of Pakistan in facing the challenges of terrorism remains the right approach.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: question asked under the 'blue card' procedure.- Dear colleague, I am glad that you spoke about the Pakistani people, because, very often, we confuse the citizens of a country with the decisions of some leaders.But I think this resolution is necessary and I ask you: can something be balanced with people's lives?We still have the death penalty there.Do you agree that there is still the death penalty in Pakistan and that we risk innocent people losing their lives for a decision by temporary leaders?

name: Sajjad KARIM
text: blue-card answer. – When a certain mind-set of individuals attack, maim and kill European citizens in Paris we all say that is wrong, but I say this to you, colleagues: when that mind-set of individuals attack us, they attack us for our values, and it is that same mind-set that then attacks innocent children in Peshawar. If we have the right to stand by our values, we must also stand by those innocent children when they are attacked.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, as we now know in Pakistan, the moratorium on the death penalty has long since ended and Pakistan has one of the most important populations in the world in the death corridor, over 8 000 people. At the same time, there is still article 295 of the Penal Code, the famous law on blasphemy, which in reality, very often, is invoked to punish matters that are anything but religious and instead to persecute innocent people and even to slap dissident religious minorities. and non-governmental organizations. The ban on social media is also another black page in the history of the country, since Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif ordered the authorities to remove all blasphemous content from the Internet pages and bring those responsible to justice, with a 23-year-old journalism student. years, Mashal Khan, who even found himself being lynched by his university mates for offending Islam during an argument. Pakistan is a key trading partner for us and must behave as such. We therefore ask that we finally return to the moratorium on the death penalty and that legislation on blasphemy that has too many holes and too many black pages is finally revised.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI). - Mr President, Pakistan is one of the countries with which the European Union is talking and cooperating in a five-year plan. The country has also been included in the enhanced Generalized System of Preferences. Nevertheless, the government of the country violates human rights, persecutes their defenders, various NGOs, journalists, bloggers and, in general, anyone who criticizes it. Even worse, it has in its legislation the death penalty, which it applies after even more problematic trials and in application of the blasphemy law. Pakistan has the sad privilege of being the country in the world with the highest number of death sentences. Unfortunately, it even executes minors and people with mental disabilities. This situation is unacceptable. The European Union must press the Pakistani government to abolish the death penalty and to respect human and labor rights. He must point out to her that if she does not comply with and implement the 27 international treaties, as she has committed herself, and the principles of good governance, she will be deprived of the right to participate in the enhanced Generalized System of Preferences.

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: - We have talked about the situation in Pakistan several times. We have always had to state that the protection of human rights in Pakistan is in a very bad state and that their defenders face persecution, unfair trials or are even being killed or disappearing. The much-criticized restoration of the death penalty continues, as does the blasphemy law, which has also imprisoned Asia Bibi for 7 years and is sentenced to death. We also intervened several times in her case. The last time I called for the suspension of the 5-year action plan in relation to Pakistan should Asia Bibi not be released. An evaluation of the plan took place in November and is set to continue, despite human rights in Pakistan being trampled on and even efforts to abolish NGOs. I therefore call again until Asia Bibi is released, until a moratorium is imposed on the reintroduced death penalty, and let us not conclude this action plan with Pakistan again.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Mr President, even though I understand the Pakistani position and Pakistan’s peculiar situation, I still believe that the current situation is not acceptable. The death penalty is a cruel and inhumane punishment that fails to act as a deterrent, and risks irreversible miscarriages of justice. I strongly support the call for the universal abolition of capital punishment, and the call on Pakistan to reinstate a full moratorium on the death penalty. The Pakistani authorities should also launch an investigation into the credible concerns of individuals with mental or intellectual disabilities or disorders who have been sentenced to the death penalty. I support the creation of a public prosecutor to investigate and prosecute attacks against journalists in Pakistan. Finally, I believe the Pakistan authorities should grant access to international observers and human rights organisations to monitor their inappropriate use of military courts. Last, but not least, I would like to mention – and also to underline – the importance of EU relations with Pakistan.

name: Amjad BASHIR
text: – Mr President, the urgent resolution on Pakistan is regrettable, misguided and misleading. I stand against abuse of human rights, wherever it may arise, but such grave allegations as these should be based on fact, not fantasy. The despicable crimes detailed are just that: crimes, against the law of the land. They are repugnant to the majority of Pakistani people and condemned by the government. To suggest that the State is behind them, has condoned them or turns a blind eye to them is simply not true. And this Parliament will demean itself if it supports the resolution. Interestingly, the text makes no mention of the delegation of the Committee on Foreign Affairs (AFET) to Pakistan last April, when we were welcome to raise any thorny issue we chose in the presence of senior government authorities, opposition parties, NGOs, think tanks and civilians, unlike similar trips to India. Pakistan relies on our help to deliver on human rights and the rule of law, as a genuine ally and economic partner of the EU and the West. This resolution sends the wrong signals altogether. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: question asked under the 'blue card' procedure.- Mr President, dear colleague, I will be very brief.I don't even use the 30 seconds.In short: do you consider it a fantasy that there is the death penalty and that there are people who are punished for taking their lives?Do you consider this a fantasy?Because you said the resolution is a fantasy.

name: Amjad BASHIR
text: blue-card answer. – I am against the death penalty. But if you mention the death penalty, how many times have you criticised one of the biggest proponents of the death penalty: the United States of America?

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Pakistani Taimoor Raza was sentenced to death three days ago for having published several comments on Facebook, in which the prophet Muhammad and his women were blasphemed. Since the government approved the abolition of the moratorium on the execution of the death penalty three years ago, Pakistan has become one of the countries that currently apply it most. But this is the first time that she has fallen on an accused of committing blasphemy on social media. This condemnation also represents another sad example of the total instrumentalization of the blasphemy law for the repression of religious minorities, for the silencing of intellectuals and human rights defenders and for the encouragement of violent revenge against the accused and their families and defenders. The lynching of Mashal Khan, two months ago, by his university colleagues shows it well. The growing wave of repression in the country, including that against humanitarian aid groups and non-governmental organizations, cannot be ignored by the European Union at the next bilateral summit and must condition progress in implementing the strategic cooperation plan.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in Pakistan, in addition to a real humanitarian emergency - since 2014, 1 340 children have died due to malnutrition - we are also facing a serious and compromised situation in terms of respect for rightshumans.Pakistan, according to a report by Amnesty International, is one of the five countries in the world where the most death sentences are imposed.In the country, activists, lawyers and all those who defend human rights are increasingly under attack, hateful laws remain, such as that on blasphemy, and no progress has been made regarding the moratorium on the death penalty.It is clear that Europe has not done all it could.However, the time has come to put more pressure on countries like Pakistan to put an end to the repression against all those who are committed to the death penalty and to the defense of fundamental rights.

name: Bas BELDER
text: - I have a specific question for the Commission.I reached extensive documentation on intolerance in the Pakistani education system: speaking hate against minorities and especially against Christians.My question is: are you aware of that?And above all: are European finances going to the Pakistani education system, which would mean that the public education system and especially the Islamic madrassas, in fact, discriminate against and actually put away Christians?I would like to make clear here the influence of the EU through the Commission.Please reply.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: - I am not generally in favor of the EU exporting its entire catalog of rights. Our concept of the charter is relatively broad, and I think it is for our space, but as far as the death penalty is concerned, it is part of the iron base of the human rights catalog, and it is really unacceptable. I think we should insist on the moratorium that was in force until recently, and if our policy is to be effective and therefore not toothless, then Pakistan really should respond to our fundamental comments. So I would very much like, thanks to the Commission's work, to succeed in pushing both the moratorium on the death penalty and, of course, the repeal of the blasphemy law or its most burning parts. It would also be good for each of us in our own approach to respond to the situation, ie. as part of fair trade, he did not buy goods that simply come from those areas where human rights are fundamentally violated. It is also about each of us, about our personal approach.

name: Jean-Paul DENANOT
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we know only too well the dramatic errors which may have resulted from the use of the death penalty. However, Pakistan not only uses the death penalty, but in addition, it uses it without any framework. Such a sentence cannot be tolerated being used against minors, and it is unacceptable that it be put into practice even before a final judgment is handed down. There have been cases of executions carried out before the trial was completed. The absence of a total safeguard against such a dangerous and inhuman instrument poses a terrible threat to all citizens, the death penalty being moreover pronounced for offenses which, in other countries, do not apply. subject of such a qualification. The case of blasphemy, which has been mentioned on several occasions, is an example. We must therefore strongly condemn the abuses of the Pakistani government and demand that it stop resorting to such a sentence. The European Union's cooperation with Pakistan obliges us to do so.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: - Mr. President, the problem of Christians in recent years is constantly growing as well as the number of countries in which it occurs. News of new persecutions is now coming from all continents. For the second year in a row, Christians are the most persecuted group in the world. It is a tragic fact that over 100,000 people lost their lives because of their ardent faith in Christ in just one year in 2016. There are countries that are not so far from the security of our European homes, and where being a Christian is the most dangerous thing in the world. One such place is Pakistan. Namely, according to the Constitution, Pakistan is an Islamic state that considers Islam as a way of life and criminal law provides for the death of those accused and convicted of blasphemy, which becomes a weapon of the new to point the finger at Christians. The charges, as well as the convictions for blasphemy, are most often arbitrary and malicious, and the consequences tragic. Christians all over the world, and especially in Pakistan, especially in the Middle East, will be completely exterminated if we do not join forces to defend them.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, we consider Pakistan as a key player in the region and we are committed to strengthening our dialogue on many issues. I could just mention they are areas as diverse as peace and security, the rule of law, good governance, human rights, migration, trade and investment, sustainable development, climate change, energy, education, culture, science and technology. This is the reason why we aim at deepening our partnership with Pakistan through a strategic engagement plan which is currently under preparation. Still, despite some progress made in the GSP+ process, the gap between the institutional human rights framework and the situation on the ground in Pakistan continues to be significant.  In all its contacts with Pakistan the EU continues to stress the importance of reintroducing the moratorium on executions. The number of executions has been reduced in the second half of 2016 and the first half of this year. We hope that this trend will lead to a definitive stop of executions and hope that this will set a direction towards finally abolishing the death penalty and towards the full respect of all international human rights obligations by Pakistan.  Yet, the extension of the military courts for another two years really constitutes a worrying element and the EU has been repeatedly calling for a comprehensive judicial reform. We are equally very concerned about the situation of human rights defenders in Pakistan. Apart from pressure and intimidation by the authorities, human rights defenders are also subject to threats, violence and even murder by extremist militant groups, and an even more worrisome trend is that allegations of blasphemy are being used to silence human rights defenders.  Yet Pakistan has established a national commission for human rights. It has adopted a human rights action plan and introduced legislation for the protection of women and children. However, there are big differences among the provinces of Pakistan as well as strong resistance against any change from religious political parties. The EU is supporting several projects to improve human rights awareness and protection in Pakistan with a total amount of EUR 97 million. We therefore encourage Pakistan to improve its human rights record and we stand ready to continue working together with Pakistan in addressing this challenge, and of course, I will pass all of your questions to the Vice-President/High Representative Ms Mogherini.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: I close the debate.The vote will take place on Thursday 15 June 2017. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. - In Pakistan, the government is implementing a very serious repression policy. Persecution, intimidation and torture against human rights defenders, political opponents and members of religious minorities are on the agenda. The death penalty is one of the most used tools by the Pakistani authorities to silence real and alleged opponents, and all those accused of blasphemy. Faced with this situation, I am very concerned for the lives of all those innocent people who are suffering the repression of the government of Islamabad. How can the European Union tolerate this situation? I would like to remind you that the action of the European Union with third countries is based precisely on the opposition to the death penalty and on respect for human rights. For these reasons, the Commission has a duty to urge Pakistan to abolish the death penalty and restore a state of democracy and respect for the rights of the Pakistani people. I believe it is essential that the European Union pay particular attention in present and future negotiations with Pakistan, in order not to compromise on the respect for human rights by the government of this populous Asian country, which has nearly 200 million people.

name: Luigi MORGANO
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the resolution on the situation of human rights and the death penalty in Pakistan, as the EU cannot remain indifferent to human rights violations and those who defend them. In particular, the resolution reports the dramatic case of Asia Bibi: in this regard, I believe it is a duty that the EU firmly urges the Pakistani government to resolve it, and not to allow it to happen again. Asia Bibi, the Pakistani Christian woman who in 2010 was found guilty of blasphemy by a Pakistani court and sentenced to death by hanging, despite the suspension of her execution, is still in prison and her family is forced to live in a hidden place. Moreover, in case of execution of the sentence, Asia Bibi would be the first woman to be executed "legally" in Pakistan, for blasphemy. I am convinced that the government of Pakistan should do everything possible to ensure the safety of Asia Bibi and her family, also in light of the "historically" treatment reserved for victims of blasphemy allegations and their defenders, as in the case of assassination of the minister of Christian minorities Shahbaz Bhatti and of the Muslim politician Salmaan Taseer.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: in writing.- Respect for human rights and the rule of law must be a priority for every state.It is therefore crucial that Pakistan makes concrete progress and timely and properly implements its adopted Human Rights Action Plan.It should be noted that religious intolerance is growing in the country.The blasphemy law reinforces discrimination and incites hatred and coercion.In addition, the use of the death penalty for blasphemy violates Pakistan’s international obligations to respect and protect human rights, including freedom of religion and expression.In this context, it is essential that the Government of Pakistan take immediate action to bring the provisions of national legislation on the death penalty in line with international law and standards and to make visible progress in this area.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: The next item is the debate on six motions for resolutions on the human rights situation in Indonesia (2017/2724 (RSP)).

name: Bas BELDER
text: Author.- Madam Commissioner, an hour ago I called a Christian, a theologian in Jakarta, and during that lengthy conversation I noticed how deeply affected Christians in Indonesia have been affected by the blasphemy case and also the conviction of the former governorfrom Jakarta Ahok.So an urgent question: is there still freedom of religion in Indonesia?I hope that the European Commission will also continue to appeal to the Indonesian government about freedom of religion and especially the fact that Christians, let alone doubly discriminated Indonesian citizens, Christians and Chinese, are currently being silenced by fanatical Muslims, who also include moderate Muslims.still threaten.Fortunately I have to say that my contacts show that there are indeed moderate Muslims who stand up for Christians.An example for Europe.

name: Barbara LOCHBIHLER
text: Author. - Mister President! In Indonesia, homosexuality has not yet been banned. However, since January 2016 the Constitutional Court has been examining a petition that aims to criminalize sexual relations between homosexuals as well as any consensual sexual relations outside of marriage. There has been an unprecedented increase in discrimination, intimidation and verbal attacks against LGBTI people over the past year, a trend that continued in 2017. It was therefore very positive that President Joko Widodo publicly spoke out against this discrimination last October. It is now necessary that concrete measures are taken to protect LGBTI people from intolerance and human rights violations. Sharia law applies in the independent province of Aceh. There, same-sex relationships are even punished with lashes - a punishment equivalent to torture. This humiliating and inhumane practice must be stopped immediately. Ultimately, homosexuality must also be legalized in Aceh.

name: Soraya POST
text: author. – Mr President, during the night of 28 March 2017, men forced their way into a private home in Banda Aceh. Two young men were beaten and insulted, then taken to the police and convicted for consensual same-sex relations. They were punished with 83 lashes in front of a jeering crowd. Such humiliating, degrading and inhuman treatment is an outrageous breach of their human rights. It may amount to torture under international law. LGBTI people in Indonesia are experiencing grave violations of their human rights. Discrimination, abuse, police raids, mandatory HIV retesting, and directives against ‘LGBTI propaganda’.  The situation is particularly severe in the Aceh region of Indonesia, governed by Sharia law. The Indonesian government must take immediate action to safeguard their LGBTI citizens’ human rights and human dignity.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Author.Indonesia is a beautiful country.Last year, 16 million tourists went to visit it for the beautiful islands, the breathtaking nature, the hospitality of the people.But today we are mainly concerned here about all the images and data that reach us today.Last week a video on the internet in which men are whipped simply because they had made love to each other.This is currently happening in beautiful Indonesia.It is not only in Aceh province, it is also in the rest of the country that LGBTI persons are being discriminated against, persecuted, booed.We have to put a stop to that.Women and girls are also victims.Do you know that half of girls under the age of 14 are currently being circumcised in beautiful Indonesia?Madam Commissioner, let us continue to take the lead from Europe.We must put human rights first.We must ask that those atrocities be stopped.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: author. - Mr. President, Indonesia is a large country, long described as a model of tolerance, particularly religious, if we except the Suharto period, which claimed at least 500,000 victims, including many communist or supposed militants. such. It is time to bring to justice those responsible for the crimes of 1965, qualified by the President of the Republic himself as crimes against humanity, as demanded by the United Nations Commission on Human Rights since 1972. The repression against atheism in this country is most often a sad remnant of this period. The country is doing poorly on many subjects. The death penalty is increasingly used in the fight against drug trafficking, including against foreigners. The case of the French Serge Atlaoui is an example. Attacks on press freedom, including against foreign journalists, are on the rise. Thus, Franck Escudié and Basile Longchamp, French journalists, were expelled on March 17. The same goes for the political repression suffered by Papuan peace activists in particular. At least 2,200 of them were arrested between April and September 2016. The same goes for blasphemy, an accusation against Governor Ahok. In addition, violence against LGBTI people is on the rise, aggravated by political rhetoric of unheard-of violence. The arrest of 141 people in a gay club on grounds of pornography on May 21 is a sad example, as are the two men whipped in public on charges of sodomy. This worrying deterioration of the situation cannot remain without consequences for the Union's relations with Indonesia. It is time to act and react by using all the means at our disposal, in particular to demand the repeal of the penal provisions which allow these incriminations. It is also necessary to obtain the release of all those who are victims of these laws of another age and the abandonment of all proceedings against them.

name: Jeroen LENAERS
text: author. – Mr President, Indonesia is a longstanding and important partner of the EU, and this is a partnership that is based on the shared values of human rights, democracy and the rule of law. It is against this background that we share our concerns here today. Concerns about what seems to be a growing intolerance against religious, ethnic and sexual minorities in Indonesia; concerns about the rising number of people that are prosecuted and imprisoned under the blasphemy laws; concerns and outrage about the situation in Aceh where two young men were publicly lashed for the simple reason that they were in love with each other. We cannot stress enough the need to protect all human rights, and particularly those of minorities. Therefore, this resolution of the European Parliament is not only criticism, it is not only concerns; it is also an open invitation to the Indonesian authorities and to our colleagues in the Indonesian Parliament to strengthen our relations and to discuss these issues with each other in a very open and frank manner.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: for the PPE Group.- Although Indonesia is a Muslim country, representatives of six different religions, including Christianity, officially live here.Although much has been said here about human rights, little has been said here that Indonesia has been seen as a country where religious freedom is steadily guaranteed.Unfortunately, in recent months we can see that various crimes are being committed on these smaller religions.Representatives of these religious minorities, especially Christians, are brutally attacked.All this is happening even though Indonesia is committed to the same values as the EU, ie human rights and democracy.This requires an EU High Representative to speak out against these practices and call on Indonesia to remedy them.I would not like Indonesia to be included in the list of countries that cannot be an EU partner because they have deviated from our values.

name: David MARTIN
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, Indonesia and the EU do enjoy very good relations, and, as the trade rapporteur, I am working to strengthen our trade and economic relations with Indonesia. However, it is important – as Mr Lenaers said – that friends speak openly and honestly to each other. The jailing of the Governor of Jakarta for blasphemy, the public flogging of two homosexual men and the other negative developments taking place in Indonesia seriously undermine our relationship. I urge the Indonesian Government to review its blasphemy law, which puts religious minorities under threat and encourages persecution. I also urge it to review the application of Sharia law, which I think is being abused even under its own terms and is certainly being used by certain sections of society to discriminate against LGBTI persons. That has no place in a modern democracy. Indonesia should act to keep itself a safe country and to keep good relations with the Western world, including the European Union.

name: Marek JUREK
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Mr Chairman! Five hundred churches have been burned down in Indonesia in recent years. Until recently, there were violent protests against the construction of a church in the heart of the country, in Jakarta. Very symbolic about anti-Christian hatred was the trial of Jakarta Governor Ahoka, who was sentenced to two years in prison for saying that Muslims could elect a Christian to public office. This simple statement that society has the right to choose a competent politician was considered blasphemy against the Koran, or - as we would say in our language - Islamophobia. Please state! It really is time for this parliament to recognize that there is anti-Christian hatred in different parts of the world, to call it by name. It is also my encouragement that the Commissioner, when summing up the debate, seize the opportunity to denounce expressis verbis the anti-Christian hatred that we see there and in very many other places in the world.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, for the last week, the world has been retweeting this photo of Indonesian football players: all praying together in harmony. A Hindu, a Christian and a Muslim – a sign of unity and tolerance. The Indonesian Government would do well by following this example.  Unfortunately, there are still many serious human rights abuses which involved the recent spike in the intolerance, harassment and violence towards various minority groups in Indonesia. The verbal attacks and acts against other religions, such as convicting and jailing the Christian Governor of Jakarta for blasphemy, must stop. The cruel punishment of sexual minorities through Sharia law by regional governments must stop. The government must put an end to discrimination by condemning and investigating all verbal and physical attacks on minority groups. Blasphemy laws must be urgently revised.  Given our even closer partnership, the EU should actively help Indonesia to fulfil its human rights obligations.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, the European Union is negotiating a new economic partnership agreement with Indonesia, a country that has so far benefited from an ever—closer relationship in various fields, especially the economic and commercial ones. Over the last decade, the Indonesian economy has more than tripled, and this is largely due to the European Union’s contribution, which is the preferred destination of Indonesian exports, as well as one of the largest investors. In addition to that, Indonesia benefits from the Generalised Scheme of Preferences (GSPs). In this context, there is a wave of growing intolerance towards ethnic, religious and sexual minorities and, in general, we have not seen the protection of human rights and the respect of international obligations. Therefore, as long as this situation persists, I strongly believe that we cannot make a new agreement. There cannot be future arrangements as long as the Indonesian Government resorts to the death penalty and fundamental freedoms of citizens are injured. An agreement will be possible only if we see concrete action and real change in government legislation.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI). - Mr President, Indonesia is a very cooperative country that interacts with the regional and international community and allows voluntary inspections of issues by third countries and organizations, although there is intolerance against Christians. First of all, the fundamental rights that theoretically govern our society are partially accepted by Indonesia. Obviously, despite the corresponding progress, there is room for significant improvement, especially in matters of religion. The Union, if it intends to appear useful and timely, without exceeding its mandate, must focus on supportive action following a sovereign decision and the call of the legitimate authorities. After all, when human rights are violated and crimes against humanity are committed, then international mechanisms are mobilized with legally binding decisions and appropriate means of action. The Union's role is, by definition, limited to highlighting human rights violations. It can lead by example, applying what it's supposed to represent to the peoples of the Member States, ensuring the well-being of its citizens and resolving internal issues. It is not enough for the Union to declare itself a pioneer in human rights, it must also prove it in practice.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: – Mr President, the blasphemy laws of the world’s largest Muslim—majority democracy represent an unlawful restriction on the freedom of expression, which disproportionately target persons belonging to religious minorities, traditional religions, non-believers and political dissidents. Of great concern are also the serious actions against the freedom of the media, the physical abuse of journalists and general growing intolerance against minorities, which are increasing together with the influence of fringe Islamist groups. I sincerely hope that, for the sake of promoting a tolerant society, Indonesia will repeal all legal provisions unduly restricting fundamental freedoms and human rights, which go beyond the provisions of the international human rights obligations it subscribed to.

name: Ana GOMES
text: - Democracy with a Muslim majority in the fourth most populous country in the world, a diverse and open society: this is Indonesia that maintains strong relations with the European Union. And so, as friends and partners in Indonesia, we are concerned about the arrest of Governor Ahok for blasphemy and with increasing incidents of intolerance against ethnic, religious and sexual minorities and the restriction of the freedoms of the majority of citizens, who are women, fomented, from the outside, by fundamentalist currents financed by Saudi Arabia and other Gulf countries and, from the inside, by nostalgic agents of the militaristic and repressive regime in Suharto. This resolution aims to encourage President Widodo and all Indonesian authorities to continue and redouble efforts to combat attempts to restrict democratic freedoms and respect for the diversity that is inherent in the national motto “bhineka tunggal ika” and Pancasila's philosophy of religious tolerance. It is unacceptable that Sharia law in Aceh serves to oppress LGBTI women and minorities and violate other basic freedoms hard-won with democracy in Indonesia. It is intolerable that medieval public scourging practices are introduced under the guise of a perverted pseudo-religious version that has nothing to do with the exemplarily tolerant way in which Islam is practiced by most Muslims in Indonesia.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: - I would like to endorse and support this motion for a resolution, because I think it is right that in the motion for a resolution we draw attention to the growing intolerance towards minorities - ethnic, religious and sexual - in Indonesia, and that we draw particular attention to the problems, which has recently been experienced by a sexual minority in Indonesia.The culmination is, of course, the situation in the province of Aceh, where Sharia law applies and where homosexuality as such is a criminal offense and there are even several dozen wounds punished for this form of sexual expression.It is therefore right, in defending the values of human rights and freedom and democracy, to warn Indonesia, which is our key partner, that it is not possible to treat minorities in this way, and to repeat this permanently in all negotiations with Indonesia.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: - Mr President, after the democratic opening that the fall of Suharto's authoritarian regime represented in Indonesia, today we are witnessing a worrying setback in guaranteeing human rights in what is the largest Muslim country in the world. In this country, women are still placed in situations of extreme submission and half of the girls are victims of genital mutilation, homosexuals and LGBTI suffer all kinds of abuse, arrests and arbitrary arrests and the blasphemy law has been a pretext for violation of the constitutional protection enjoyed by the various Hindu, Buddhist and, above all, Christian religious minorities. The European Union cannot fail to condemn these violations and to make the free trade agreement negotiations with Indonesia conditional on compliance with international human rights obligations that bind that country, including the restoration of the moratorium on the death penalty with a view to the its abolition and respect for the very motto of the Indonesian shield that we Europeans also share: “united in diversity”.

name: Jean-Paul DENANOT
text: - Mr President, we can indeed congratulate ourselves on the progress made in economic and social matters in Indonesia, thanks in particular to the partnership with the European Union. But we must remain very vigilant on the questions of freedoms and human rights. In particular, we must reject all attacks on religious freedoms and sexual preferences. Everyone must, in fact, be able to live according to their aspirations and personal orientations. Of particular concern is the rise in intolerance, noted by many international observers. We must therefore urge the central government to be vigilant on these questions of rights and freedoms and forcefully ask it to review the freedom-killing laws of another age. Aceh's torture session should prompt him to pay particular attention to what is happening in his provinces. And then, in Indonesia as elsewhere, we cannot accept that freedom of expression is violated and that journalists are imprisoned. The European Union must weigh on Indonesia to bring this country to its senses.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: - Indonesia is a democratic country, but one that is growing intolerance.Although this country has made undeniable progress in economic development, ensuring, say, social security for its citizens, in terms of religious freedom, violence against women or even against sexual minorities, the situation is really bad, tragic.A few dozen wounds that are a punishment for people who live their private relationship with another person of the same sex, so I think this is completely unacceptable.I can understand this if the state regulates some kind of public expression, but if someone in the private sphere lives their own life, whether religious or sexual, then I think it should remain in their freedom, and we should clearly speak out against such punishment.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, as many Members noted, the European Union has friendly and close relations with Indonesia based on the solid framework of our EU-Indonesia Partnership and Cooperation Agreement. We value our close partnership with this country. The EU has always had the highest regard for Indonesia’s tradition as a pluralist, diverse and tolerant society but we acknowledge incidents that might call this tradition into question now. Members of this House have raised a number of human rights issues in Indonesia, including the situation of the LGBTI community, media freedom, the application of the blasphemy law, the rights of the minorities, women’s rights and Christians’ rights. The EU has established a constructive and cooperative engagement on human rights in the form of a regular human rights dialogue with Indonesia, which allows for an exchange also on very sensitive subjects. We had the sixth Human Rights Dialogue last June and we are planning for the next meeting later in this year. We also use other available opportunities to discuss human rights issues, through traditional diplomatic tools. The EU has encouraged Indonesia to abide by its international human rights commitments under the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights (ICCPR) and to ensure that national and regional laws, both in their formulation and implementation, do not discriminate against any of its citizens. In regard to LGBTI persons, we welcome the statement by President Joko Widodo last October, when he said the police must act, that there should be no discrimination against anyone and that protection should be ensured.  The right to freedom of religion or belief is guaranteed in Indonesia’s constitution. The European Union has consistently stated that laws that criminalise blasphemy can, when applied in a discriminatory manner, have a serious inhibiting effect on freedom of expression and on freedom of religion or belief. We note that the Constitutional Court reviewed the blasphemy law in 2010 but found it not to be in violation of the constitution. We note renewed debate about the law in Indonesia, where the EU has made its voice very hard. Let me add that several projects are funded under the European Initiative on Democracy and Human Rights, on freedom of religion and belief and protection of minority groups. Be assured that the EU will continue to use every opportunity, including the next EU-Indonesia Human Rights Dialogue, to continue to raise the relevant issues with our Indonesian counterparts.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: I close the debate.The vote will take place on Thursday 15 June 2017 (the sitting was suspended at 11.40 and resumed at 12.00)

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: After the barbarity of the terrorist attacks in recent weeks, another horrendous tragedy has hit the city of London. We all saw dramatic scenes again: a skyscraper on fire, with many dead, unfortunately, with many missing. These are scenes we would never want to see. Unfortunately, we risk that the situation will get worse and that there will be other victims. This story is a drama for the city of London, a drama for the UK, a drama for all of us. On behalf of the European Parliament, I want to thank all those involved in the rescue operations, hundreds and hundreds of firefighters, women and men of the police. People who risked their lives to save the lives of others. Dear colleagues, this is why I ask you, once again, to join me in a minute of silence to remember the innocent victims of the London tragedy. (Parliament stands, observes a minute's silence) Positive news certainly cannot cancel the pain that affects the British people and the families of the victims also, it seems, from other countries of the European Union. However, today I feel proud to remember that the era of roaming in the European Union is over. This is a great achievement. (Applause) Citizens, students, business travelers and tourists will be able to move throughout the Union at no additional cost for their calls or for using the Internet. We are building another important piece of our single market, of our being European. I am grateful to Parliament for bringing a battle that lasted years to a successful conclusion, if we think that the first time this House spoke out against excessive roaming costs was back in 2005. Since then we have fought to have them steadily diminish, up to the complete abolition of roaming which we can verify starting today. I would like to thank everyone who has by name contributed to this extraordinary achievement over the last decade, but the list would be too long.However, allow me to mention the colleagues who in this Parliament have led this long battle to a successful conclusion: del Castillo, Kumpula-Natri, Toia, Ford, Rohde, Harbor, Matias, Reimon, Tamburrano, Rübig, Tošenovský, Ferreira, Borrelli, Fontana.(Applause) And a special mention to our colleague and Vice-President of the European Commission Viviane Reding, to whom we are all grateful for her great contribution.(Applause)

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Mr Gollnisch has raised a point of order, and then I will give you the floor, bear with me.

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: - Madam President, my reminder relates to Rule 150 of our Rules of Procedure. I am, alas, already a very old member of this Parliament and I must say that I observe with great concern the reduction in the guarantees represented by parliamentary immunity, the sole legitimate purpose of which is to guarantee freedom of expression. policy of the deputy when he is pursued by political opponents or when, as a member of the opposition, he is pursued by a government or by hostile administrative authorities which act through public prosecutors. This is no longer the case. It is completely scandalous that in a Parliament like ours, which claims to be the guarantor of public freedoms and the presumption of innocence, the person concerned does not have the opportunity to speak in session, that the legal committee is summoned under absolutely chaotic conditions, which are unworthy of our rules, that it is not the same deputies who attend the hearing of the person concerned and who take the decision, which obviously vitiates the decision in question ... ( The President cut off the speaker)

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Please, colleagues, may I have order? Mr Gollnisch, I will close your microphone now and I will respond. Mr Gollnisch, please listen to the Chair. Mr Gollnisch is referring to our first vote, which we will get to presently. I will reply to your concerns. Mr Ehler, you have a point as well. Please raise it now.

name: Christian EHLER
text: - Madam President, my colleagues!Most of you will know that yesterday there was a serious attack on colleagues in the American Congress in Washington.In the run-up to a charity event on a sports field, the majority leader of the American Congress was seriously injured by a shot in the stomach.Other MPs have also been shot injured.Police officers have prevented the worst, saved their lives and been injured themselves.I believe that it is an expression of our transatlantic solidarity and our good relations with the American Congress that we convey our wishes for improvement to the seriously injured and that we deeply condemn this attack and the police officers who saved the lives of the Members of Parliament in order to guarantee parliamentary freedom and securityguarantee, thank you.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Thank you, Mr Ehler. We all support your kind and important remarks. I refer now to the question about immunity and I will read the rules. Rule 9(6) provides that the Member concerned is given the opportunity to be heard by the committee responsible and the Member concerned – and we will vote shortly – was invited twice to appear before the committee, but did not accept either of those invitations.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The next item is the vote. (For the results and other details of the vote: see Minutes)

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: - Madam President, in the debate we have had today, members of different political groups, the one of which I am a member, the Socialist Group and the Liberal Group, have expressed a desire to postpone the vote.Therefore, I invite you to put this wish to a vote.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The proposal is to postpone the vote. Would anyone like to speak against the proposal?

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: – No, just to confirm that the ECR Group will endorse and support the position of the EPP in asking for a delay in the vote, as suggested by Commissioner Hahn.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: I am asking whether there is anyone in the Chamber who wishes to speak against. You have the floor.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: – Madam President, in fact we had a debate today in the plenary, and it was consensual in terms of the assessment of the situation; there was not a single voice that would evaluate the abduction in a different way. So the question is, what is the best tactic? Some of the colleagues have proposed postponement for one reason, and that is that Commissioner Hahn will have an opportunity, travelling to Baku, to raise the issue – or he has already travelled – but the point is, we have considered this an urgency and all political groups have agreed. Everyone knows, including the person detained, as well as the Azerbaijani Government, that we are discussing and eventually postponing it on the request of Mr Hahn, for the reason that he would like to be in a better position. That is not correct. My assessment is different. If we postpone it, that basically means that we accept the disrespect of President Aliyev in that a few days before the abduction he received for an hour and a half an EP high ranking delegation discussing human rights, and then this is done. I do not believe that that will achieve the goal.  A final remark – what will achieve the goal is if the Commissioner has in hand a well—balanced wording of a resolution that will help to strengthen his position in order to release the gentleman.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: – Madam President, it is important to check all the possible facts and mistakes, and there is one factual mistake in paragraph 8. In fact, the body of Mehman Galandarov,  the blogger and activist who died in the custody of Azerbaijani authorities on 28 April this year was returned to his family, so can I propose as an oral amendment that we delete the last part of paragraph 8 which is as follows ‘and whose body was not returned to his family?’. It was returned.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: That concludes the vote.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: In line with your suggestion, we waited a moment for everyone interested in participating in the debate to stay, and those who were not interested to leave.I appeal to colleagues who are still in the room and are not speaking to move their internal discussions outside the conference room.We pass to the explanations of vote.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: - The European Fund for Strategic Investments has been in force for almost two years. However, the east-west division in it is still very visible. As of 30 June 2016, the EU-15 received 91% of the fund from EFSI support, while the EU-13 received only 9%. I was alarmed to learn that instead of supporting various projects, the European Investment Bank is using the European Union guarantee to promote projects that raise doubts as to whether they comply with established project selection criteria. I would like to add that for over a year now we have been hearing from representatives of GERB how with the help of this fund in Bulgaria a project for an interconnector with Greece would be financed. However, this still remains only in words and promises. This project should finally be given priority, and not be used only in PR campaigns, because it is in the interest of national security.

name: Rosa D'AMATO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the innkeeper has told us that he has good wine but we would be very hurt if we got drunk with the numbers he keeps giving. The praises of the EFSI have been made according to the data provided by the EFSI designer. There has been no independent evaluation and we have gobbled up the narrative of a successful investment plan that supports small and medium-sized businesses, that has added value and that drives growth and jobs. However, none of this, disaggregated data on real benefits are lacking, the multiplier effect has been overestimated, there is no information on the jobs created, the operating procedures are opaque and the figures are sometimes classified. Even the European Court of Auditors has made it clear that EFSI has a limited impact. Not only that, many projects have high impacting emissions. There are many interventions for fossil sources such as oil and gas and very little is done for renewables and to support energy self-production. Meanwhile, high-risk financial instruments are multiplying for an EFSI that winks at banks and financial intermediaries, but which risks being a time bomb for real economies. For this reason we have voted against.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: Ms D’Amato, your metaphor about wines was very interesting!

name: Daniel HANNAN
text: – Mr President, it is always about the money, is it not. How much time we spend in this Chamber talking about transfers of cash! We never think about the debilitating effect it can have on individuals, on whole professions, consultants and contractors, and the people who have learned how to make a living out of the Brussels institution, even on whole nations who are encouraged to look beyond their borders for every rise in life.  We have evolved a whole special vocabulary to talk about how we keep the money going round. For example, the word ‘greed’ is always used for somebody who has a claim on somebody else’s money. It is never used for somebody who wants to keep his own resources. The word ‘solidarity’ is used when we European politicians arrange a transfer.  I would make one warning, one note of caution. If you vote for politicians who have promised to give you somebody else’s money, do not complain when they take your money to spend on somebody else, or indeed to spend on themselves.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Mr President, I would like to draw your attention to the fact that the European Fund for Strategic Investments has benefited mainly those countries that do not have big investment gaps and it creates an unequal geographical distribution of funded projects. Now the competition is going on: which comes first? The positive result of cohesion and investment policies for the Latvian economy or huge demographic change in Latvia.  Many people have left the country because they are tired of waiting for the Latvian economy to reach western and Nordic EU economy levels. They prefer to emigrate with their families. The shrinking working-age population will not offer any prospects for those who remain in the country. As a result, we will see a beautiful but empty country with a small, old and poor population.  The Latvian economy needs investment from the European Fund for Strategic Investments, and distribution should be made without any discrimination. I support the report and especially the idea of providing technical assistance to those countries and regions which have benefited less from the European Fund for Strategic Investments.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: - Mr President, I supported the resolution on the report on the implementation of the European Fund for Strategic Investments, as this is one way of increasing investment in the European Union for projects that could increase employment and prosperity.This own-initiative report contains many good suggestions on how to improve the functioning of this new tool and to improve communication with citizens and businesses alike.However, I would like to emphasize that improving the investment climate cannot be just a matter of public investment, but above all of private resources.Well thank you.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: - President!I voted in favor of the report on a European agenda for the Community economy.Like the report, I welcome the fact that the recovery of the Community economy will increase competition, but I also welcome the fact that the text also addresses the impact on the labor market and workers' rights.My vote was also positively influenced by the fact that the report addressed the needs of rural areas on several points.I agree that the Community economy can create significant opportunities for the hinterland, rural areas and disadvantaged areas.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Mr President, the collaborative economy creates new opportunities for our societies and would make an important contribution to jobs and growth in the European Union. but the main challenge is to find a proper definition of what the term ‘collaborative economy’ means. An answer should be found for some important issues related to consumer protection, employment relationships, tax rules and other issues. The collaborative economy enables people to work according to flexible arrangements. This makes it possible for them to become economically active where more traditional forms of employment are not suitable. But at the same time we should be careful. Sometimes new platforms and technologies are only used to avoid labour and tax legislation. This creates unfair advantages and puts pressure on other market participants to do the same. As a result, we see a race to the bottom that can have a very unpleasant and unpredictable economic, social and political outcome. I think this report is a step in the right direction.

name: Lucy ANDERSON
text: – Mr President, the collaborative economy in areas such as travel and leisure has had a large potential to enhance the everyday lives of citizens and to create quality jobs. But it must be regulated responsibly to protect from exploitation workers and consumers involved in or relying upon these new business models. Equally, it is essential to ensure that taxation and other public policy priorities are regulated by this and are dealt with properly in the collaborative economy.  The text of this report reflects these concerns and I was pleased to vote for it.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: - Mr President, I supported the report on the collaborative economy presented, albeit with some embarrassment.Until I read it, I thought that there was no difference between a collaborative and a market economy.I am therefore pleased that own-initiative reports such as this broaden my horizons and give me the opportunity to look at familiar phenomena, such as division of labor, specialization and, consequently, the necessary cooperation in the exchange of goods and services, with a whole new eye.However, it will probably be a long time before the discourse on the collaborative economy enters European legislation.Well thank you.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: - The fragmentation of the European Union's digital market significantly weakens its global competitiveness. The lack of funding for new market technologies, as well as legal uncertainty, are a serious obstacle for European start-ups. Small and medium-sized businesses are the backbone of the European economy and we must provide the necessary incentives for its development. I call on the European Commission to continue to promote the growth of online platforms in the European Union, because they provide much-needed benefits for small and medium-sized enterprises, such as access to global markets and the opportunity for growth. It should also be noted that providing online access for startups saves them the exorbitant investment in digital infrastructure by providing them with widespread distribution. Moreover, it seems insane to me that we are talking about the distribution of 5G networks, while at the same time in most rural areas in Bulgaria, for example, there is no 3G and 4G coverage. For these reasons, I gave my support to the report.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: - President! The report made a number of proposals for consideration, including online platforms and the digital single market. One of the most important of these is the call for adequate investment in the expansion of high-speed broadband networks and other digital infrastructure. I particularly welcome the fact that the report also covers rural areas in terms of investment in infrastructure, and that it has spoken out against unequal access to technology. Member States must actively work to prevent gaps due to a lack of digital skills or unequal access to technology. I now support the call for the development of the social dimension, and I also call on the Member States to ensure adequate social security for the self-employed. I also agree with the findings on the importance of combating the dissemination of false news, the protection of personal data and the provision of information to consumers.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – I voted in favour of this report in the light of the hard work that the rapporteurs, Ms Virkkunen and Mr Juvin, have done to evaluate the issues central to the consolidation of online platforms and a digital single market in the European Union.  I welcome the report’s thorough appraisal of innovative opportunities and regulatory challenges in this sphere. Essentially, the report also evaluates the digital transformation of Europe in terms of the collaborative economy and the transparent processing of data across digital platforms. By identifying the means of responding to these challenges we can bolster the digital single market and the competitiveness of our markets for the future. I wish to note the vital contributions of my colleagues in the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy towards the finalisation of this report. I am pleased to voice my support, and I am expecting SMEs and citizens to benefit as we create a digital single market.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Mr President, conflict in Yemen is not a popular theme of discussion in European media. This is leading to our usual European problem: selective blindness. One part of this blindness exists because of a lack of concentration in European society. The problem exists only if people see the emotional stories on TV or in social media. If not, the problem does not exist in people’s minds at all. As a result, politicians are free to do nothing to resolve this bloody conflict. Many European politicians are not being frank about the situation in Yemen. The political elite of some EU countries are silent because of the interest in the arms trading deal with Saudi Arabia. Money has no smell. We Europeans are also responsible for the victims of this ongoing conflict because of our silence, and are fuelling this war by selling weapons to groups in the conflict zone. We in the European Parliament like to criticise other countries, but we are not critical of ourselves. I supported all the amendments of the GUE Group and the Greens in this resolution.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: - President!I voted in favor of the motion for a resolution on the status and funding of European political parties and foundations, as I believe that, due to the many shortcomings, 1141/2014 is needed.recast of RegulationMainly in terms of the level of co-financing and the possibility of multi-party membership.That is why, in agreement with the motion, I urge the Commission to study the shortcomings and propose a revision of the regulation.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: - Today, I supported the EP resolution on the financing of political parties and foundations at European level.I believe that we need more transparency.European democracy needs democrats, free and responsible citizens, because that is the only way it will be viable.I think it is a mistake that the current system of financing political parties is parasitic.In this system, groups promoting the anti-European agenda are parasitic.That is why we also called on the Commission today to review the current regulation as soon as possible and to present a revision of it, which will combat the misuse of public funds.Personally, I particularly support transparency in adjusting the funding conditions, raising the mandatory limit for MEPs' membership of a European political party from one to at least three MEPs, and calling for clear political affiliation for MEPs.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: - Mr President, in its resolution, the European Parliament calls on the Commission to draw up an amendment to the rules for funding European political parties and foundations.In a sense, I agree with the petitioners that some changes are probably needed.However, I understand the concerns of small political parties and foundations, for which some types of change could have direct liquidating consequences.That is also why I believe that both the Commission and this Parliament should be sensitive and prudent in this matter.We, as Members of the European Parliament, must follow this process, we must comment on it and we must be active.We cannot wait until the final text when it will not be possible to change much.I also insist that, if we are to change the rules in the future, they should only be effective from the beginning of the new parliamentary term.Well thank you.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: – Mr President, every few years this House tries to change the rules governing European parties. Apart from entailing a lot of work in each successive debate, this is not good for stable democracy in the EU. That is my opinion. The proposal raising the number of MEPs needed to create a European party is unhelpful for the much-needed dialogue between the EU institutions and citizens in the EU. It gives a strong impression that you need to be inside the Brussels bubble in order to become part of it.  If you need three to five MEPs to create a European party, that will close the door to any initiative from the bottom up, the kind of initiative that the EU now needs most. Not all small and new parties are anti-EU. This measure will not stop far right groupings, but it will be undemocratic, as it closes the doors on basically all new parties in the future. That is not the message which we should send to our citizens.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: I hereby close the explanation of vote.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the major question under Rule 130b of the Rules of Procedure by Beatrix von Storch, Daniela Aiuto, Kristina Winberg, Joëlle Bergeron, on behalf of the EFDD Group, on the celebration of International Family Day 2017: promoting the role ofParents in ensuring quality education for their children (O-000030/2017 / rév.1 - B8-0315 / 2017) (2017/2736 (RSP)).

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Author. - Madam President! The reason for this debate today is International Family Day, and the United Nations has published a handout for it. According to the United Nations, mother and father are the most important point of reference in the lives of children and especially toddlers. Young children are best socialized within the family - within the family rather than outside the family, says the United Nations. And the more fathers and mothers take care of their children, the better things go in their children's lives, say the United Nations. The educational achievements of parents are measurable achievements that are economically and socially relevant and which must therefore be promoted, say the United Nations. In summary, the UN say: The most important thing for children in their lives are father and mother - their parents - and not an all-day kindergarten or external care. You notice that this is the exact opposite of what religion seems to be here in this house. The European Union prefers to sponsor week nurseries like in the Eastern Bloc and in the GDR. Mothers shouldn't take care of their toddlers, but they should realize themselves at the workbench, because only that is true achievement and career. And in the Noichl report we actually decided that marriage - of course only traditional marriage and not gay marriage - and the role of father and mother are dangerous to health. That is probably also the reason why it is not the responsible Commissioner Jourová who is sitting here today, but the Commissioner for Health. Family a health risk. The EU simply does not want to recognize the importance of the family and the role of father and mother, when it is the most important thing in a child's life. But there are Member States that are on the right track. Hungary, for example, recently held a demography summit under the Orbán government. They had previously launched a number of family policies that do just that - promoting fathers and mothers for their children and for early childhood education. So they exist, these Member States, who have taken the right path, and I hope for Germany and also for the European Union, but especially for my country Germany, that we will take this Hungarian path in terms of family policy. And that means that we must move completely away from the path that is being followed here in this House and turn towards the path that the United Nations describe: The most important thing in life for a child is father and mother and families and not the state as higher authority; that is the belief here, that is fundamentally wrong. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the blue card procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: a question asked by raising a blue card.- I was quite provoked by my colleague's speech, it was interesting in many ways, but I want to ask my colleague whether, given her political status, the speech means that she wants family-related things to be regulated, resp.regulated at European level.Do I understand correctly that in this way you actually want to enter, in my opinion, into the rather distinctive position of the EU Member States?

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Answer to a question about the “blue card” procedure.- Thank you for that question.Of course, this is precisely not the case, absolutely not.The families should be free of state interference and in particular without interference from the European Union.It is not at all the competence of the European Union to interfere anywhere.But what we do from this house - we get involved, we run awareness-raising campaigns and campaigns for all possible forms of life and so on, against fathers, against mothers.We should refrain from doing that.So, first of all, we interfere and then in the wrong way.No interference, national responsibility - that is a very clear message.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I will not repeat questions, but simply say ‘question 1’, etc. Let me stress that EU Member States may observe the International Day of the Family in their capacity as United Nations members. Observing the day offers a good opportunity to discuss the role of families and the impact of family-oriented policies in promoting overall well—being in Europe and worldwide, and in the world of work more generally. As you know, Member States are, first and foremost, responsible for social policies addressed to families. Nevertheless, the Commission has been supporting Member States through political guidance in the context of the European Semester. European Union financial support is also available through the European Social Fund, the European Regional Development Fund and the Fund for European Aid to the Most Deprived. Concerning the roles of families in educating their children, the Commission reiterated in our recent communication on school development and excellent teaching that the cooperation of educational institutions and parents is key. We will continue to use the tools under the Education and Training 2020 Strategy and the Erasmus Plus programme to support Member States who wish to develop school policies that deepen parental involvement. Second question: we share your view on the important role played by families in the welfare of our societies, in particular when it comes to providing care for children and other dependent family members. This is precisely why the European Pillar of Social Rights adopted on 26 April 2017 recognises the role of family members as caregivers and states that parents and people with caring responsibilities have the right to suitable leave, flexible working agreements and access to care services.  As a concrete deliverable of the Pillar, our new initiative on work—life balance for parents and carers aims to modernise the way in which work—life balance policies are designed to improve the daily lives of many parents and carers.
