In addition to supporting the provisions of formal care services, we intend to update the European Union legal framework in the areas of family—related leave and flexible working arrangements in order to enable working parents and carers to better reconcile their professional and caring responsibilities. In addition, the Pillar includes the right to affordable early childhood education and care of good quality. It also states the right to protection from poverty and the right to specific support measures to enhance equal opportunities for children from disadvantaged backgrounds. Early childhood education and care is precisely such a specific measure which helps to break the cycle of disadvantage. This is why the Commission supports Member States in improving access to, and the quality of, early childhood education and care. We acknowledge that family is the first and most important place for children to grow and develop. At the same time, the Commission sees early childhood education provision and the family’s role in education as complementary. Participating in early education is in the best interests of children and their families. It is in these formative years that we can lay the foundations for a successful life, social integration and employability. The Commission therefore considers that the provision of early childhood education is an indispensable part of an efficient and modern social infrastructure. We are also monitoring the implementation of the 2013 recommendation on investing in children. In the context of the European Semester, the Commission has provided targeted, country—specific recommendations to those Member States with the biggest challenges, and we are supporting the exchange of good practices in the area of child and family policy through the European Platform for Investing in Children and the Erasmus+ programme. The Commission also provides financial support to various NGOs, including Eurocarers, the Confederation of Family Organisations in the EU, Eurochild and the European Network on Independent Living. The actions undertaken by these NGOs substantially contribute to raising awareness of issues related to the work of family members. Third question: we share your concern regarding the invisible or unpaid work of working parents and carers. This is why the Commission put forward this new initiative on work—life balance for working parents and carers. This sets out a comprehensive package of complementary legal and policy measures which will enable both parents to care for their children, thus enhancing their children’s cognitive development and well—being. As regards European Union funds, the funding possibilities for children in the existing EU financial instrument have been significantly strengthened in the current 2014-2020 programming period. Approximately EUR 21.2 billion of the total European Social Fund’s allocation was earmarked for social inclusion measures, of which EUR 3.9 billion is set aside for access to services, including childcare, and EUR 8 billion was earmarked for measures to prevent early school leaving. Moreover, around EUR 11 billion from the European Regional Development Fund is planned for measures promoting social inclusion and combating poverty, while around EUR 6 billion are planned for investment in educational infrastructure.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: for the PPE Group. - I think we are all aware of the primary role of parents in raising children. Parents have and must continue to have free choice and also responsibility for the upbringing and education of their children. We want parents to be a partner for the school. We have all highlighted the risk of poverty, in which almost one third of children in Europe still live today. Among the most endangered are those who live with one parent or even without a stable family background. Although the average of incomplete secondary education has been reduced, more than 10% of children still do not complete their education and are at risk of life failure. The role of parents and grandparents is unquestionable. Just as the competence of the Member States in family and education policy is unquestionable. The EU should help them in this mission. Europe's society is aging and will age if we do not realize that a child is an investment. That is why we in the EP should highlight parental care for children as the most important human work that we value, and we must also appreciate it financially. I call on the Commission and the Member States. Let us create conditions for parents so that they can and want to have and raise children. It is the best investment in our future.

name: Urszula KRUPA
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Madam President! I would also like to point out that, unfortunately, many activities are not entirely favorable to the family, which - as we know - is the natural environment for raising a child. The Barcelona cells encourage women to work, despite the fact that, according to research, a significant proportion want to personally look after their baby after its birth. Meanwhile, it is proposed that most children should attend pre-school education. According to Norwegian studies, the level of stress in children in nurseries is as much as 30% higher than in those staying at home. Especially in young children, prolonged stress has a very negative effect on development, especially on the brain. It has been proven that the more time children spend in a nursery, the more anti-social attitudes they show, and teenagers brought up in nurseries after the age of 15 more often use alcohol, cigarettes or drugs. Personally, I am also against introducing special incentives for fathers to raise newborns instead of mothers, because they need a more delicate, caring and sensitive personality to the needs of the newborn. The period of childhood plays a huge role in proper development, when the child unconsciously identifies with its mother until the second year of life. Later, for a female child, the mother remains a model, while for boys, in the third year of life, identification with the father begins. The difference in interests of male and female children is noticeable from the earliest moments of life, which proves that gender differentiation is built into the cognitive process in the womb.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: on behalf of the ALDE Club. - Madam President, I am very glad that this item is on the agenda of our Parliament today because I want to say very clearly that it is very good to celebrate International Family Day, because the family is certainly one of the foundations of society. However, on the other hand, I want to make it clear that I do not allow a monopoly on the family to someone who comes only from the right political spectrum, the family belongs to all of us. I also speak here as a proud father of three successful children, who already have their children, so I have grandchildren, and I am very joyful and happy about it. I am convinced, on the other hand, as a man who is not exclusive, that all that our wider community, public childcare institutions, can do, there is also no alternative. What parents can do, there is no alternative. But what public institutions can do with the knowledge and experience that people who work in public institutions have, we must not underestimate. What I still want to emphasize is that of course we do not always and everywhere just happy marriages, we also have a number of problems, so we have to talk about it. We must also discuss the fact of the existence of same-sex marriages, a topic that we must not reject and we must not reject children raised in such marriages. I support this debate, I think it is welcome, but I also expect the Commission to also steer this debate in a balanced and acceptable way for all of us in this House.

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Madam President, dear colleagues, the family is the basic unit of society. It is based on the natural complementarity between men and women, on welcoming life from conception, on education, which is carried out by families and not by States, which must help families. Can we however say that this Parliament or this Commission is on the side of families? No, unfortunately no. Can we speak of families and carers in the face of the austerity policy which has destroyed the family budgets of many Member States, which destroys and reduces life expectancy, as in Italy, with the demographic winter from which our nations, especially in the south? Can we speak of family when we want to impose on Member States minority family models through aggressive LGBT and gender propaganda, repeated, repeated and repeated every time in any motion? Can we speak of family when we leave thousands of Europeans without hope of a better future for their children and when we open up to immigration, when we already have 50% unemployment in our areas, politicians, under the terms of the United Nations? Ma'am, I have two minutes. (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: - Madam President, every debate in the European Parliament should begin and end with a debate on the impact of European policy on the family. We are facing a problem associated with a low birth rate and an increasing average age of the population. However, we still refuse to see not only the unpaid work performed by women mothers in the field of childcare, family members and the household, but also the important role of parents in ensuring quality education and upbringing of children. Our labor market and pension systems punish fathers and mothers who choose to raise children. The time they devote to them is a barrier for employers and leads to lower wages and pensions. Being a parent is not worth it. The solution is not individualization of policies, but family mainstreaming. Every policy has an impact on the family, and this needs to be quantified in advance. Only in this way can we make political decisions that will improve the situation of families and rejuvenate Europe and achieve sustainable prosperity. - Madam President, allow me to say one remark to the Commissioner. Mr Commissioner, I would like to ask you not to use ‘reconciliation of private and professional lives’; it is ‘family and professional life’. Private and professional is not the same.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: Mr. Schaffhauser!I had it checked again.Your group has two minutes in total - one minute for you and one minute for Mrs D'Ornano.Please, Mrs D'Ornano, you have the floor.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, this family day comes at a time when this fundamental social structure is threatened, judging by the proliferation of single-parent families and the decline in the birth rate. A reminder of the role of the family in the education of children is essential, especially at a time when this task is too often entrusted to the school, which is already responsible for education. However, many studies confirm the link between a favorable family environment and academic success. It is therefore essential to protect the child by guaranteeing him the family balance to which he is entitled. I support, of course, the taking into account of the invisible work accomplished by mothers and fathers. However, as stated in the United Nations resolution, cited in support of this text, respect for the diversity of the social systems of the Member States justifies measures at the national level.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, let me first say 'Happy Birthday' to all the families in the world. I am a convinced family woman, I have just turned forty years of marriage. We must recognize here that there are two reasons why we have problems with children in families. On the one hand, poverty, where families can neither support them nor educate them, and there, in rural areas, we need nurseries, kindergartens, but we must, at the same time, increase the standard of living, so that children to sit next to their parents. The second cause: I have identified it in many countries and recently it is the case in Finland. There are loopholes through which, through national legislation, there is an excess of zeal in taking children from their parents, for one reason or another. We have the case of that doctor from Finland, where the two children, right now when we are talking, are separated from their mother, the mother being a doctor and being able to take care of them. Nowhere can children feel love and peace, only with their parents and I believe that we must act here. There is subsidiarity, but I think we can intervene so that, on the one hand, there are no excesses in the adoption of children from the family and their institutionalization and, on the other hand, we see how we invest in education, in order to increase families' incomes, in order to be recognized, for example, in retirement, maternity leave should be in a larger amount, so that we can motivate, because we are not well with the demographics.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: - Ms. President! I would like to mention three things briefly. I would also like to recommend at least one of this to the Commissioner, namely that in Hungary, although the government is very proud of taking a lot of family-friendly measures, all through the tax system, wealthier families can enjoy family benefits, the unemployed or those on lower incomes. and they fall out of it. I would like the Commissioner to help to regulate at European level that puts this practice further down. The other thing I would like to mention, and it is a great pain in Hungary, is that there are also a lot of refugee families who are literally imprisoned at the Hungarian border, for example, as long as the investigation, the examination of their asylum application and if someone raises it. against his word, then Viktor Orbán says that the European Union supports terrorists. Well, these should be eliminated.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, first of all I would like to congratulate all in this room and all around the walls on International Family Day. I am a father of three children and grandfather of three grandchildren. I am a medical doctor; I have spent a lot of time doing my job, and know all about the complexity.  Of course we must all agree about all human rights, about family lives, about children’s lives; of course we must seek balance and how to move forward with progress, and of course our common goals remain to improve the life chances of every family and every European Union citizen. This is why we put forward ambitious proposals such as the European pillar of social rights and the work-life balance package. This can address issues with work and life at home and what you mentioned about private and other things.  This is an agenda which needs to fully engage all stakeholders, in particular Member States. Of course, it must be in line with the subsidiarity principle, because we have no chance to intervene in the Member States’ area of responsibility: absolutely, it is crystal clear. We must also look at the situation of proportionality. We are ready to play our part, but the centre of gravity of social policies such as family—oriented policies is – and will remain – with national, and especially local, authorities, because they are very close to families. The primary responsibility for making social rights a reality lies with national governments, national parliaments and social partners, and we will continue in this way of cooperation and support and see how we can move forward.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: Thank you, Commissioner.Please let me also talk about something personal: Both of my parents were always gainfully employed and I grew up in a very happy family.I am very, very grateful for that.That closes the debate.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the major question under Rule 130b of the Rules of Procedure by Curzio Maltese, Martina Michels, on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group, on video platforms and editorial responsibility (O-000035/2017 - B8-0318 / 2017) (2017/2737 (RSP)).

name: Curzio MALTESE
text: author. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, having to discuss online platforms, I expected to discuss with another Commissioner, but thank you for his presence. I would also like to set up the discussion in such a way that it concerns health and also the family, which is important to all of us. For example, we could have been the parents of an Italian girl from Naples, Tiziana, who killed herself a year ago because the videos of her sexual relations had ended up on the net, on Facebook, for a revenge from her ex-boyfriend and had become viral. The girl could no longer leave the house, she was the victim of persecution, harassment, a kind of collective rape, until she hanged herself. For many months the videos of the dead girl continued to circulate on Facebook, in a macabre rise in audience, until an Italian court ruling blocked them. But Facebook's lawyers in Ireland, who look after Facebook's interests in Italy in order not to pay taxes in Italy, have obtained that the company in any case does not suffer any sanctions and have appealed to European legislation for this. I don't know if this seems justice to you, it doesn't seem to me. We have an e-commerce directive which excludes online platforms from editorial responsibility. A directive that is seventeen years old, when e-commerce did not exist, platforms were just born and were really a pure vehicle for sharing content and information, and in addition the technologies did not allow ex ante control of the contents entered. Network. Today the world has changed, you all know that. E-commerce is the largest growing business on the planet, platforms are global players, economic giants that devour entire production sectors, concentrate quantities of resources and power, threaten media pluralism. Fortunately, however, the advances in science allow us today, with increasingly sophisticated algorithms, to control i contents on the net in a very short time. Despite this, Facebook and Google, which are able to destroy a person's reputation in an hour or influence the outcome of an election campaign by hosting fake news campaigns, continue to be less responsible than a small local broadcaster, a small provincial newspaper, which for a cause may risk closure. But the most serious trait concerns us as parents, because the weakest element of this unfair and sick market is only minors, children, who are exposed to a bombardment of deceptive advertisements through deceptive product placement advertisements, they are exposed to a bombardment of bad habits, such as junk food, and of course they are the victims of other worrying phenomena that are expanding on the net such as hate speech or child pornography. Instead of rhetoric about the family, we try to defend our children from these risks. So the Commission does not think that this unfair market should now finally be regulated with fair and modern criteria, which protect consumers, especially the weakest, especially minors, starting to revise the e-commerce directive as soon as possible. ask many European countries starting with Italy?

name: Curzio MALTESE
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, the Commission shares broadly the problem analysed and presented by the honourable Member. One of the main objectives of the European Union is to protect vulnerable groups, including minors, consumers and citizens in general through harmonisation of laws. The Commission is fully committed both to safeguarding freedom of expression and protecting vulnerable viewers – children in particular – from harmful content, and all citizens against hate speech. Article 14 of the e-commerce directive needs to be interpreted on a case—by—case basis. While the e-commerce directive prohibits Member States from imposing a general monitoring obligation on providers, it requires providers to act upon obtaining actual knowledge of illegal activity in order to avoid liability.  The Commission believes that progress can be made without reopening the e-commerce directive, which has been a major contributor to innovation and societal benefits. The European Union has proposed targeted measures to ensure that platforms take action against specific problems, such as illegal hate speech and terrorist propaganda.  The Commission has also initiated and strongly supported co-regulatory efforts. The Commission communication on the mid-term review of the Digital Single Market of 10 May 2017 announced a better coordination of dialogues with platforms, focusing on the mechanisms and technical solutions for the removal of illegal content. This communication also announced the Commission’s guidelines on two topics: first, coherent procedural aspects such as the notification and removal of illegal content; second, on liability rules and support to platforms on voluntary measures taken by the platform when they work proactively to remove illegal content, acting in good faith. The Commission is currently reflecting on the most appropriate form for such guidance.  The issue of protection of minors and hate speech on video-sharing platforms is addressed by the proposals of a review of the Audiovisual Media Service Directive adopted on 25 May 2016, which is currently under discussion by the Council and Parliament. The Commission proposal foresees a limited extension of its scope to video-sharing platforms, for example YouTube. The proposed system seeks to keep the balance between the fundamental right of freedom of expression and important public interest objectives, such as the protection of minors against harmful content and the protection of all citizens against hate speech.  According to the proposals, only those rules that are necessary to protect the viewers from the most harmful content will apply to video-sharing platforms. Member States should ensure that video-sharing platforms put in place measures to 1) protect minors from harmful content, access to which would have to be restricted, and 2) protect all citizens from incitement to hate.  The measures consist, where appropriate, in establishing and operating flagging and reporting mechanisms, age verification systems, systems to read the content by the uploaders or users, or parental control systems. It is important to stress that none of the measures included in the proposal entail a general obligation to monitor or ex—ante control; it is fully in line with the e-commerce directive.  Member States are encouraged to implement the new rules via co-regulation. The involvement of the industry will ensure that measures are future-proofed and that platform is built on what they are already doing on a voluntary basis. Some platforms are indeed already making great efforts to protect minors online and citizens from hate speech. Through the implementation via co-regulation, we are aiming to a building on the work already done. However, there are services that do not have such measures in place. Now all video-sharing platforms will be obliged to take measures. The Audiovisual Media Service Directive would provide regulators with a regulatory backstop in case there is no action from platforms. In addition, video-sharing platforms today apply their own standards when it comes to assessing what is harmful for minors or what constitutes hate speech. The Commission proposal aims that they have to comply with the Audiovisual Directive standards in this field.  The Commission believes that the proposed rules will ensure a better protection of viewers in online services. The Commission is also looking forward to the upcoming trialogues, and hopes to secure the adoption of the revised Audiovisual Media Service Directive as soon as possible, as this is a priority file and identified by the institutions.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: for the PPE Group. - I would just like to begin by saying that I also reported catch-the-eye on the previous point and only 2 colleagues from another faction were given the floor. I am not complaining, I just want to sign up for the catch-the-eye on this point, where I would make a speech and comment on this issue. I would like to thank my colleague Maltes for making this point. I would add one more to the hurtful example he gave. In the Czech Republic, the existence of a game for young children, adolescents - the Blue Whale, which was supposed to force them to commit suicide, was actually verified by the police. This absolutely shocking example only demonstrates how necessary it is to really regulate the content of this information, which is disseminated in a completely confusing manner in the digital age and actually has room for such dissemination on the free internet. I know that it is very difficult to interfere with the freedom of the Internet. This is always a critical moment. On the other hand, at a time when we have such vulnerable groups of children and adolescents in mind, I think we should proceed, as the Commissioner has indicated. Finding that balance is very important.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. - Ms. President! With varying degrees of severity and content across countries, but across Europe, our common experience is that young generations are re-infected with different manifestations of human hatred and intolerance, the poison of extreme nationalism, racism, anti-Semitism, xenophobia. The phenomenon is particularly well known in Eastern and Central Europe, where the dangerous varieties of anti-Semitism are striking, among the youngest, almost childhood populations, which led to the extermination of millions well before their birth and even the birth of their parents, whole peoples, generations. to its priceless suffering and irreparable losses. In researching the reasons for this terrifying trend, we first come across the most unscrupulous representatives of the political extremism, who do not shy away from the mental poisoning of young people, or from tolerating it from a position of power, in order to achieve their obscure political goals. The responsibility of the government and other factors responsible for education cannot be avoided for failing to arm the younger generations enough against the return of the ordeal of our history, and there are even examples of signs of this appearing in the curriculum itself or in official government policy. The latter, unfortunately, is now a global dimension, the cyber war by Putin's Russia and organized falsification of news. And when looking at the tools, today they provide the most obvious, and perhaps the least transparent and verifiable, space for this dangerous phenomenon, to which children and juveniles are most susceptible, including, for the first time, the video-sharing platforms under discussion today. That is why our common thinking today is so important that I think it should be translated into joint and effective EU action in the short term. Despite the fact that, as a European Democrat, I also hate any restrictions on freedom of information and expression, I hate all forms of censorship. protection of our children and grandchildren against the proliferation of inhumanity, racism, anti-Semitism, in particular, not even the curse of censorship in the eyes of a European citizen who has experienced it in reality.

name: Jozo RADOŠ
text: on behalf of the ALDE Club.- Madam President, first of all I would like to thank my colleague Maltese for opening this important issue.According to today's rules, ie this Directive we are talking about, service providers are not obliged to follow the content they publish, and they are not responsible if they do not know that some content is illegal.At the same time, Member States can obtain information on service providers, thus identifying who it is, but this indirectly means their obligation to monitor the content, which in fact means that there is a great responsibility of Member States and probably the inability to monitor the whole process.minimum liability of the service provider.This situation is certainly not good and that is why I welcome the Commission's readiness to work to protect all citizens, especially those who are the weakest, namely children and the elderly, when amending this Directive and other similar directives.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I confess that dealing with such complex issues in just one minute is really difficult. I know both the case of Tiziana Cantone - I come from the same region - and the case of the blue whale, which a colleague mentioned earlier. However, in this case, we are talking about crimes and I beg to differ. In the e-commerce directive it does not say that platforms are not responsible. And if we want to say that Article 14, paragraph 3, is not working, I agree and if we are willing to reopen the directive to find a more stringent way to protect European citizens, I agree perfectly. However, on the other hand, these are crimes and we must also think about freedom of expression. Are we really convinced that the simplest solution is to give private individuals a power that belongs to the judicial authority? Often these individuals are big companies, are often or almost always non-Europeans, and have a monopoly status. And so I wonder where the limit begins and where the freedom of expression ends. Another separate discussion concerns advertising. I believe that the latest form of protection for children is truly guaranteed by the abolition of advertising that belongs to them. The clear and precise rules of commercial communications should instead be contained in an ad hoc legislative act, which concerns advertising on all media. Finally, we invest in civic education and digital education for European citizens.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: I know that one minute is an imposition on some topics.Unfortunately, your group only gave you a minute.That's why I can't just let time run by.I'm sorry.Catch-the-eye procedure

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: - The media, the internet, child protection - this is a topic that we consider essential, and I look at where there are colleagues who have called for fundamental parental responsibility.Of course, the responsibility of parents to protect their children is their priority, but I think that if the Internet knows no borders, we must also ask what the legislative conditions are.I believe that the mandatory removal of illegal content is not censorship.I think this is an abuse of the trust of children who are vulnerable.The Internet, as I said, has no borders and therefore belongs to the EP, and I thank the Commissioner, who mentioned here the Audiovisual Directive, which is in the legislative process and introduces the responsibility of ISPs for removing harmful illegal content.I think that is a fundamental measure that we must take.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, of course, it is clear from the few speeches here, because it is a pity that we are few, that something needs to be done. There must be a responsibility of the platform owners. We can't have fake news. Not only do we destroy the image of a person or even the family, but we have life problems here. There are children who, as it has been shown here - and in our country, it's that stupid game with the blue whale - the children die. It's not possible. Sure, we are in the age of digitization. I am glad that, Madam President, you are a supporter of consumer rights. This is where this consumer's right comes into play, to be protected, and we urgently need to intervene with a regulation of responsibility: to make everyone responsible for false information. This does not mean that we do not want freedom of the press, but we want to hold those who circulate information on online platforms accountable. After all, we have discussed a lot in the IMCO Committee, Madam President, this online and offline trade must have the same conditions, the same consumer protection, the same conditions.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: - I would like to add to what my colleague Šojdrová said.Indeed, the role of parents is very crucial, we must all be aware of this, and in this sense we should also support the family and parents.This is how I want to comment on the previous serious interpellation.Unfortunately, in my opinion, there is an indirect proportion.The more we talk about real family support, the less real support families receive.I am aware that this is primarily the responsibility of the Member States.Of course we have to talk about it.I am glad that topics such as equal pay for equal work, but also the issue of pensions, which, in my opinion, should be based on the principle of merit, came to the talks this week.The person who raises the children, who are then payers of the pension scheme, should also be rewarded with merit by not receiving less pension in retirement.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, we have had a very interesting exchange of views, and, as the honourable Members have rightly mentioned, this is a very complex issue. We need not only to do something, but we need to take the concrete actions which the Commission presented and see how to move forward.  The Commission is fully committed to protecting minors and to ensuring freedom of speech. This debate will certainly help us in our internal work to prepare targeted measures to ensure that platforms take action against hate speech or content which is harmful to minors. I also welcome this debate in the context of the upcoming trialogue for the adoption of the Audiovisual Media Services Directive. We look forward to the rapid adoption of this directive and future work between the institutions to respond to the challenges of the platforms’ economy. I would like to say once again that we need to have good collaboration and quick reactions and a good trialogue, and to see how to move forward in more concrete ways, keeping account of all the questions which have been raised.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: That closes the debate.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: I declare the session of the European Parliament adjourned.(The sitting was closed at 3:55 p. M.)
